dialogues.speaker: B.C.
dialogues.text: The scene is introduced by the blowing of desert sand. When it clears we are on a very long shot toward the sea. On the shore of the sea there is a small and simple Egyptian house with e smaller outbuilding. There is the suggestion of movement there, as if there are people, but what this movement is can't be distinguished, for at this distance the house itself seems a tiny thing in the midst of a vast desolation. The brassy waters of the sea stretch endlessly. For the rest, there is only empty desert and a circle of dry, red hills. We hear the lonely howl of a jackal, then -

dialogues.speaker: OLD SINUHE'S VOICE
dialogues.text: On the surface of the earth there is no more desolate spot than this.

dialogues.speaker: MORNING
dialogues.text: Gamera goes along with a small whirlwind which, beginning out of nowhere, whirls past the house, where camera stops It is a simple house, made of mad bricks, its formerly bright colors faded and weather-beaten. in the shade of &@ small entrance porch SINUHE is seated. He is 95 years old. He is writing on a scroll of papyrus which runs across his knees. It seems that he has written much and has little left to write, for the roll of completed manu- seript on his left hand is large and the roll on his right hand is small. The passing of the small whirlwind disturbs him hardly at all as he bends over his scroll.

dialogues.speaker: MORNING
dialogues.text: He writes in Egyptian hieroglyphics. The hands which make the marks are cramped and wrinkled; the marks they make are clear and incisive - the marks of a man whose thinking has crystallized into knowledge. As he writes -

dialogues.speaker: OLD SINUHE
dialogues.text: I - Sinuhe the Egyptian, write this -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as he continues - (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sue lk (Cont.)

dialogues.speaker: OLD SINUHE
dialogues.text: ~ the last chapter. He stops writing for a moment, looks up, and we see his eyes. As a dying fire retains a heart of glowing coals, so does this man preserve in these eyes the fire of his dying life -- remarkable eyes, which are sometimes alert with intelligence, calm with resigned philosophy, spar- kling with mature and ironic humor, or touched with pain. He looks at the desert, the hills, the sea; bendsover to write.

dialogues.speaker: EARLY MORNING
dialogues.text: Brassy water. Alkaline sand. Sparse vegetation.

dialogues.speaker: OLD SINUHE'S VOICE
dialogues.text: Before me stretch the brassy waters of the Red Sea.

dialogues.speaker: MORNING
dialogues.text: An Egyptian monument of some sort, half crumbled into dust, shows in the distance.

dialogues.speaker: OLD SINUHE'S VOICE
dialogues.text: Around me are the ancient dry hills and desert.

dialogues.speaker: EARLY MORNING
dialogues.text: Near the small outbuilding four Egyptian SOLDIERS are relieving their boredom by hurling spears at a post tar- get. Midway between outbuilding and house are boundary stones,

dialogues.speaker: OLD SINUHE'S VOICE
dialogues.text: Boundary stones mark the limits of my dwelling place. Those are my guards ~- I am in exile.

dialogues.speaker: MORNING
dialogues.text: for a moment looks over to the guards, then, bending over his task again -

dialogues.speaker: OLD SINUHE
dialogues.text: How can it be that a man ends his life in such a fashion? I, who am called He Who Is Alone, am writing this --  10 il 12 13 ih Sue 3.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: are listening to the sound of Sinuhe's voice, their heads cocked, their shiny eyes blinking.

dialogues.speaker: OLD SINUHE'S VOICE
dialogues.text: - that some day it may be dug from Egypt's sands and read.

dialogues.speaker: OLD SINUHE
dialogues.text: He looks up from his work, considering the possibility of this last thought, half in hope, half in doubt. Then he sees the lizards, and his expression alters. He is not surprised to see them, and amiles at them as friends.

dialogues.speaker: OLD SINUHE
dialogues.text: But who knows what tomorrow will bring? I eam very old, and I may never finish, eh?

dialogues.speaker: LIZARDS
dialogues.text: The original pair, their heads cocked as they listen to Sinuhe. Two or three more run in.

dialogues.speaker: OLD SINUHE
dialogues.text: For a moment leans back, wiping weariness from his eyes. Then, an idea striking him, he looks at the lizards again.

dialogues.speaker: OLD SINUHE
dialogues.text: I'll tell my story to you --

dialogues.speaker: LIZARDS
dialogues.text: perk up. Their beady eyes give them an air of being raptly interested.

dialogues.speaker: OLD SINUHE'S VOICE
dialogues.text: - my only companions now.

dialogues.speaker: OLD SINUEE
dialogues.text: smiles in a rather odd way -

dialogues.speaker: OLD SINUHE
dialogues.text: (with just a trace of bitterness in humor) You have learned not to shun me <- you listen when I speak. Then, warming to his idea, he begins to unroll the papyru scroll slowly backward. ( CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 5h2 14 (Cont.) 15 16 17 OLD SINUHE (Cont.) I shall tell my story backward - the way a story should be told - for a man winds the years of his life on a scroll. Then unrolling the scroll more rapidly, with wide sweeps of his arm - Let the scroll unwind!

dialogues.speaker: PAPYRUS SCROLL
dialogues.text: being rapidly rolled backward.

dialogues.speaker: OLD SINUHE'S VOICE
dialogues.text: Half a century! - to a day when I was forty-fivel

dialogues.speaker: DAY
dialogues.text: in f.g., to give perspective, is a shadoff (irrigation derrick) with which a bent, old FARM SLAVE buckets water from a smell irrigation ditch into a smaller ditch. In b.g. is the city of Thebes on the Nile River, its many- pyloned temples contrasting with its md hovels, its city of the living on the East bank, city of the dead (cemeter etc.) on the West.

dialogues.speaker: OLD SINUHE'S VOICE
dialogues.text: I lived in Thebes - capital of Egypt, on the Nile -- and I shall tell you the kind of world in which I lived ---

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The building is being erected of great limestone blocks. We see ordinary WORKMEN who shape the stone with crude instruments and set the stones in place - but the focus of interest is a great sledge on which a huge block of stone is being transported. Forty SLAVES, hitched like oxen to the sledge, are trying to pull it up a wet-sanded ramp. OVERSEERS, who carry staffs as tall as themselves, do not hesitate to belabor the backs of the salves. Sinuhe, dressed in the clothing of a physician, stands watching.

dialogues.speaker: OLD SINUHE'S VOICE
dialogues.text: For every free man there were a hundred in bondage. ( CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She 17 (Cont.) 18 19 One of the slaves drops senseless to the ground, from starvation and exhaustion. Sinuhe walks to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sinuhe bends over the slave, examines him. He pushes back his eyelids, looks into dead eyes. He rises, shakes his head at those who have gathered around. There is no expression of horror on Sinuhe's face -~ this is the daily life of these people, not an isolated incident. Camera pulls back to widen angle as an indifferent Overseer shrugs, whacks the harness of the dead slave free with the slash of a large knife. Another Overseer, raising his staff -

dialogues.speaker: OVERSEER
dialogues.text: {shouts command) Hot - and Overseers' staffs whack down on the backs of the slaves, who struggle, pant and sweat again.

dialogues.speaker: HOUSEHOLD SLAVES, ENTERTAINERS
dialogues.text: (For a portion of general atmosphere see NAT'L. GEOGRAPHI Oct. 1941, p 46h.) Under a portico facing a garden a NOBLE lies on a bed. He is fat and wealthy and his body glistens with 011. He has a swollen, gouty foot, which rests on a cushion on the floor. Sinuhe, kneeling there, is bleeding him, using the instrument of his time, of copper and stone. Nearby is the small, wooden, portable box in which he carries his instruments and medicines. Sinuhe also observes the scene. A SYRIAN SLAVE MERCHANT, unctuous and fawning, is offering for the inspection of the Noble a string of WOMEN SLAVES. These slaves are of all ages, countries, colors of skin - and the action of the selling goes like this: As the merchant brings the women and girls forward for inspection, they arrive in such a way that we see their faces, can judge their nationalities, beauty or lack of it, their ages. But as they are presented to the Noble their backs are to camera. Before the Noble, they lift aside their garments, so that he may inspect them as one would cattle. The Woble indicates with a gesture of his ivory-handled fly- whisk his decision. All who are presented at the opening of this scene the Noble waves away with indifference. Seated beside the Noble's bed in a chair is the NOBLE'S WIFE, a haughty, proud, indifferent woman, dressed in formal wig, much rich jewelry, the finest dress. If she (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She 19 (Cont.) 20 pays any attention at all to the business between her husband, the salve dealer and the women, it is no more than to give a momentary and indifferent glance. She cools herself with a revolving fan and her haughty look is directed for the most part to the garden, where some entertainment is being staged. There, two WRESTLERS, one black, one white, are engaged in a match. HOUSEHOLD SLAVES and HOUSEHOLD OFFICERS watch. Other ENTERTAINERS, including a group of semi-nude DANCING GIRLS wait their turn to attempt to relieve the lady's boredom.

dialogues.speaker: OLD SINUHE'S VOICE
dialogues.text: Though 8 man might have but one wife, he could own as many women as he could afford. Camere moves forward to a tighter scene at the Noble's bed. The next slaves are hardly more than children, girls of no more than thirteen, fair of face and figure. As they display themselves before the Noble, his eyes at last glisten with interest and desire.

dialogues.speaker: OLD SINUHE'S VOICE
dialogues.text: There was no word in our language mean- ing sin. The Noble tosses some money - silver rings - on the floor The Merchant scrambles for them greedily. The Noble motions the new slaves to come closer. Sinuhe, as if by accident, but not by accident, drops his medicine chest on the Noble's swollen foot. The Noble screams in pain and anger. But, as camera pulls back, Sinuhe, with a calm manner of indifference, picks up his case and walks away.

dialogues.speaker: SHOT
dialogues.text: Scene begins on top a huddle of roof tops, all jammed together, no courtyards - homes of the very poor. Camera moves down into a narrow, dirty street, teeming with humanity. One can almost smell the stink in the heat and feel the bite of flies. Most of the people are of the poor WORKING CLASS, but there are FOREIGNERS too: A HITTITE, with a high pointed cap and heavy pointed boots; A SARDINIAN BODYGUARD, with ball and horns on helmet; A LIGYAN BOWMAN with two bright feathers in his leather skull cap; A MITANNI TRADER in his draped and fringed garb of Babylon, pushing through with a couple of loaded donkeys .... Nearly naked children play in the street, boys at four-times-around and girls at bali. They scatter ( CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 5u2 20 (Cont.) 21 press against the walls as a procession comes through - a tribute-bearing mission, en route from the docks to some temple or palace. These people are from the southern land of Kush, ebony black MOORS with incredibly thick lip and ostrich feathers in their caps, animal-eyed women with children carried in baskets on their backs. The men lead animals on chains: a couple of snarling panthers on ohains, a baboon with a long mantle of grey hair, grey- hounds. As this line of people clears, our moving camera is approaching a group of men who are gambling, throwing dice, squatted in the dirt. A woman who is preparing to fry fish on an open brazier before her hut, cleaning the fish, acatters the entrails wherever - some hit one of the gamblers, who is angry, but his companions laugh.

dialogues.speaker: OLD SINUHE'S VOICE
dialogues.text: For the great majority it was a world of dirt, of poverty, of disease and death. Some of the fish guts hit against Sinuhe's robe as he passes the gambling group. Moving camera pulls back with him as he comes along, carrying his portable medi- cine case, on his way to pay a professional visit. He has to stop as a dead body is carried out of one of the huts, the body wrapped carelessly in a shroud, a stiff leg showing. Sinuhe observes this only as an everyday eccurrence. A couple of steps later he has to stop again as a line of PRISONERS are led across this street from one side alley to another. They are guarded by SOLDIERS. Their elbows are bound behind their backs. They are alike in their poverty and in a symbol which all wear stitched onto their clothing. It is the ankh, or cross of life; something similar to the Christian cross, except that above the crossbar there is a loop:-. Sinuhe watches them as they are led away to slavery, or worse. His face hardens with anger.

dialogues.speaker: GODDESSES OF EGYPT
dialogues.text: These deities can be presented as statues against sky or wall backing, as low-relief and painted sculptures on walls, They should be selected from the most grotesque, primitive and fearful - in their animal-headed representa tions ~ and might include: Bes, Set, Ipet, Sekhmet, Anpu, Tet, Thoth, Hapi, Bast, Sebek, Khonsu...

dialogues.speaker: OLD SINUEE'S VOICE
dialogues.text: It was a world of superstition - of fearful worship of a hundred ancient gods. ( CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 5h2 8. 21 (Cont.) 22 The last of these is the deity MONTU, the falcon-headed god of battle, on which we arrive during: But the deity most feared and wor~ shipped, the living god, was Pharaohl

dialogues.speaker: PALACE ATTENDANTS
dialogues.text: Camera angle is slightly down, toward floor, and camera is advancing over a sea of backs of people who are pros~ trate on their faces before the throne of Pharach. We do not see the throne at first, nor Pharaoh. These people range from palace SLAVES to SOLDIERS, MILITARY OFFICERS, COURTIERS, OFFICIALS and ROYAL PRINCES AND PRINCESSES. All carry their proper insignia of office -- projecting above these backs are military weapons, staffs and the tall ostrich fans of the most high, most near the throne. Arriving at the foot of the throne, camera stops. Tethered there is a lion, which lies on the floor. Camera pans slowly up, picks up the golden sandals of Pharaoh and his Queen, then their legs, then themselves. HOREMHEB is standing stiffly before his throne chair, impassively surveying the multitude. On his head is the double crown of Egypt, tall, hat-like, red and white - with the sacred snake~head, the Uraesus. His hands carry the lash and the crook, the black and white crook in ceremonial posi- tion, just underneath his jeweled collar. Many charms in the shape of stiff emblems and variously kmotted and looped ribbons hang down from his hips. On the wall be- hind him there is a magnificent mural of a battle scene which shows Horemheb bloodily slaying Hittites. (The decorations of this room are all very military; the atmos phere of this court is predominantly military.) At 45 this warrior-King has not lost his military carriage; his physique is magnificent. His face, furrowed by battle is also eroded by care and secret unhappiness -- his soul is sick. His queen, BAKETAMON, is already seated in her chair of their double throne. She, also, is bedecked with full ceremonial clothing, wig and jewelry. A little more than a year older than Horemheb, she is still a most beautiful woman, with finely chiseled, aristocratic fea~ tures - showing the inbreeding decadence of a long line of royalty. She is completely impassive; her dark eyes have no sparkle but look ahead like the unseeing eyes of a statue of a goddess -- she is a woman who has totally withdrawn from life. Horemheb sits into his throne chair. Taking his time, he looks to his left and down at someone on the floor.  5k2 23 2h 25 26

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Prostrate like the rest, he nevertheless has an eye on Horemhebd. EJE is a very old man, tall, thin - with the look of an ascetic gone sour ~ a crafty look. A slight signal from Horemhebd gets him to his feet -~ he gets up painfully. With his staff of office he raps on the tiled floor.

dialogues.speaker: ALL
dialogues.text: as all rise - but silently, no buzz. Their faces toward the throne, we see them arrayed, all in their places according to their ranks, The highest nobles nearest, their ostrich fans now forming a canopy over Pharaoh and the Queen, Behind the right hand of the double throne are two youths, boys, sons of this pair, already warriors in character,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as a slight motion from Horeitheb brings Eie to his side. Horemheb's look asks a question; Eile bows; Horemheb look toward a side door to the room. On his face there comes a strange expression - there is anger, but lurking behind it a kind of indecision, as if he dreads what is coming. Then decision takes over and he gestures sharply. Eie turns toward the side door and his staff raps an order.

dialogues.speaker: DAY
dialogues.text: Sinuhe is brought in. His elbows are bound behind his back. Four SOLDIERS guard him, led by an OFFICER who carries a whip of office. All watch as Sinuhe is brought toward the throne. Near throne the officer stops the soldiers and all prostrate themselves, leaving Sinuhe to come before the throne alone, On his clothing is sewed the emblem of the cross of life. He does not prostrate himself before Horemheb, but looks him in the face calmly

dialogues.speaker: EIE
dialogues.text: (outraged) You stand?

dialogues.speaker: HOREMHEB
dialogues.text: (sharply, out of corner of mouth) Leave off. He is returning Sinuhe's look, for this is between the tw of them. It is a flood of rising anger which Horemheb is trying to control now. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: HOREMHEB
dialogues.text: (after rather long pause, as if in wonder) Were you and I once friends? For a moment there is a flicker between them as they each remember - but the flicker is all the response there is from Sinuhe -- the human connection between the two is cut off as if by a switch.

dialogues.speaker: HOREMHEB
dialogues.text: (as Pharaoh, struggling against rising rage) You are Pharaoh's friend no longer. I have been patient with you, Sinuhe, but I can be patient no longeri He is shaking with rage. His hands grip the arms of his throne chair until his kmuckles are white. He pulls him- self to his feet.

dialogues.speaker: ALL
dialogues.text: Ag at this movement from Pharach all go on their knees, soundlessly, automatically, like mechanically operated figures. Only the Queen, seated on her throne chair, and Horemheb and Sinuhe, confronting each other on their feet are on a higher level than the others.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Horemheb comes down a step of his throne until he is near Sinuhe but still towering a step above him. He points accusingly at the emblem of the cross of life on Sinuhe's breast - then suddenly rips it off the garment, tearing part of the garment with it.

dialogues.speaker: HOREMHEB
dialogues.text: (insensate with rage) I could strangle you with my own hands\ Sinuhe's only answer is a slight broadening of his ironic smile. Baketamon turns her head slowly toward them. For the moment the goddess-stare leaves her eyes and she is a woman looking at two men.

dialogues.speaker: BAKETAMON
dialogues.text: (with an edge of scorn) Whatever. Pharaoh will do, let him do it quickly. Both men look at her. Sinuhe's look is a rather odd one. It is colored with the irony that he has shown Horemheb. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 5h2 ll. 28 (Cont.) 29 30 But there is something else, too, which tells that these two have known each other as people, also. He almost imperceptibly inclines his head, the barest indication of a bow. Baketamon looks away from his look, looks straight ahead again, assumes the official look, the blank stare.

dialogues.speaker: HOREMHEB
dialogues.text: (blustering because secretly abashed) He is no more than a pebble between my toes. He sits on his throne chair again. Those in scene are seen to rise, indicative that all in court rise. Horemheb looks at Sinuhe again.

dialogues.speaker: HOREMEEB
dialogues.text: I banish you from Egypt. Never more shall you see this land watered by the Nilel (with growing rage again) Live your days in lonelinesst May your grave be unknown and your name forgotten! (leans back exhausted) Pharach has spoken}

dialogues.speaker: SINUHE
dialogues.text: {after a pause, still with irony, still with a smile) So be it. He turns and walks back in the way he entered.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as his guards fall in with him, taking him from the room.

dialogues.speaker: HOREMHEB AND BAKETAMON
dialogues.text: in beg. the Queen looks straight ahead, not moving. Horemheb looks after Sinuhe - with rage - and with some- thing else, which, strangely enough, seems to be shame.

dialogues.speaker: SCROLL
dialogues.text: on which Sinuhe is setting down the cross of life.

dialogues.speaker: OLD SINUHE'S VOICE
dialogues.text: Why did Horemheb not put me to death? Was it the memory of friendship? (shakes his head) What did he not dare say in the hearing of the people of his court? During which -

dialogues.speaker: SINUHE
dialogues.text: as for a moment he thinks, looking off, then looking at his "audience."

dialogues.speaker: OLD SINUHE
dialogues.text: Let the scroll unwind againl - With a sweep of his hand starts the scroll rolling back- ward.

dialogues.speaker: SCROLL
dialogues.text: rolling swiftly backward.

dialogues.speaker: OLD SINUHE'S VOICE
dialogues.text: - To a morning on the plains outside Thebes - when Horemhebd and I were twenty-five! We hear the sounds of the running horses and of chariot wheels, then -

dialogues.speaker: HOREMHEB
dialogues.text: going with a chariot in which Sinuhe and Horemheb are riding. The location is across the river from Thebes, some distance out from Thebes, and the city may be visibl in far b.g. in this shot -- (or, if not in this shot, in some shot during the following sequence - one shot bein, sufficient for the purpose of establishing the location). The terrain is plain bordered by hills - lion country. “The hills are punctuated by small canyons, notably one box canyon, which is important to the action to follow. The chariot is going at high speed, quartering toward camera. It is pulled by a TEAM OF HORSES at a gallop.

dialogues.speaker: JUST BEFORE SUNRISE
dialogues.text: Horemheb has the reins. Strapped to the chariot are quivers for arrows and for spears. Sinuhe and Horemheb are on a hunt. At 25 both are vigorously young, healthy, bursting with gay spirits.

dialogues.speaker: JUST BEFORE DAWN
dialogues.text: They are hunting lions. A pride of these animals can be seen between chariot and hills.

dialogues.speaker: PRIDE OF LIONS
dialogues.text: comes into action at the approach of the chariot - scatte running - a number of them toward the box canyon. This group is led by a large MALE LION who sports a great blac mane.

dialogues.speaker: HOREMHEB
dialogues.text: {points ahead) The Black Mane!

dialogues.speaker: SINUHE
dialogues.text: Cut him off!

dialogues.speaker: AT MOUTH OF BOX CANYON
dialogues.text: Chariot arrives too late. The black maned Male and some other lions make it through the narrow entrance to the box canyon, Horemheb, thwarted, momentum carrying the chariot beyond the mouth of the canyon, starts to swing around in a circle so as to head the chariot directly at the mouth of the canyon.

dialogues.speaker: SINUHE AND HOREMHEB
dialogues.text: as Sinuhe begins to show a little apprehension. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: AS
dialogues.text: She

dialogues.speaker: SINUHE
dialogues.text: We follow him in there? For answer Horemhebd grins like a warrior in battle, whip the team.

dialogues.speaker: JUST BEFORE SUNRISE
dialogues.text: The entrance to this place is narrow. The canyon pene trates but a short distance into the hills, ending in a sac or amphitheater of cliffs, hugh rocks and caves. One might call it a lion's den for here in caves lions breed and live. The place swarms with them. There is @ lioness with cubs, The black maned Male. All are in an uproar, increased by the sound of the approaching chariot Some of the lions, including the black maned Male, leap up onto the great rocks, out of reach.

dialogues.speaker: AT MOUTH OF CANYON
dialogues.text: coming in with Sinuhe and Horemheb in chariot. Sinuhe seizes a spear in each hand. Horemheb, looping reins around his neck, takes his bow and a fistful of arrows. Almost immediately the team of horses has to pull itself up, rearing, pawing the air, as it arrives at a rock barrier.

dialogues.speaker: AT CHARIOT
dialogues.text: A maelstrom of action. Roars, dust. Sinuhe and Horemheb whipped up to the apex of excitement. A lion, leaps from a rock directly over Chariot. Sinuhe turns to look, having practically felt the lion as it went over. He hurls a spear, missing, the spear shatter- ing on rock. The black maned Male leaps past, rushes out of the canyon. Horemheb grabs the reins, seems to pull his team around by main strength, sets out in pursuit,

dialogues.speaker: SUNRISE
dialogues.text: The black maned Male leaps out, streaks across plains. Short interval. The chariot with Horemheb and Sinuhe emerges.

dialogues.speaker: JUST BEFORE SUNRISE
dialogues.text: streaking across the plains again. ‘The lion disappears over a ridge Chariot after.  she 46 47 48 49 50 51 52 53 15.

dialogues.speaker: BEFORE SUNRISE
dialogues.text: This is a peaceful spot. A small area of clean sand dunes (If city of Thebes in distance has not been seen in the first shot of this sequence, this shot is suggested as an alternative.) Atop a hillock there is a piece of archi- tecture which is obviously a shrine - a small shaft (of the kind we call Cleopatra's needle.) Kneeling at the base of this shaft is AKHNATON. Young (20's), frail, handsome to the point of prettiness, ascetic. He is almost in a trance of reverie. Sound, distant, of chariot approaching. Camera pans over. Coming up a defile di- rectly toward Akhnaton is the lion. Then chariot appears behind, angling obliquely in pursuit.

dialogues.speaker: LION
dialogues.text: raging, leaps past camera.

dialogues.speaker: AT SHRINE
dialogues.text: pays absolutely no heed. From the ground he takes an armful of waterlilies which he has brought with him to the shrine, lays them at the base of the shaft.

dialogues.speaker: JUST BEFORE SUNRISE
dialogues.text: It is apparent that Akhnaton is in great danger, for the lion, in his frenzy to escape, can easily tear him to pieces.

dialogues.speaker: IN CHARIOT
dialogues.text: Horemheb whips the team in an effort to intervene between the lion and Akhnaton. Sinuhe, with bow and arrow, is trying to get a shot at the lion over the backs of the horses, but can't.

dialogues.speaker: AT SHRINE
dialogues.text: looks around - but only with an air of being somewhat troubled at being disturbed, and showing no trace of fear

dialogues.speaker: SUNRISE
dialogues.text: The chariot arrives just in time - lion veers off - but the chariot is overturned, spilling Sinuhe and Horemheb out into the sand.

dialogues.speaker: AT SHRINE
dialogues.text: watches them, through the film of sand and dust thrown up by the smashup. Then he returns to his reveries, looks to the east with tense expectancy.  5u2 5h 55 56 16.

dialogues.speaker: AT SHRINE
dialogues.text: Sinuhe and Horemheb pick themselves up from the sand, both very angry. :

dialogues.speaker: HOREMHEB
dialogues.text: (yells over) Idiotl He rushes to quiet the team of horses and right the chariot. Sinuhe, equally angry, comes to Akhnaton.

dialogues.speaker: SINUHE
dialogues.text: Don't you know you could have been killed! Akhnaton looks at him, his eyes burning with such inten- sity, that they seem almost mad. In a voice which has a strange, delicate, almost:feminine quality, and given an added strangeness by the choked intensity of his emotions he says:

dialogues.speaker: AKHNATON
dialogues.text: The god is coming. (looks eastward) As Sinuhe reacts with astonishment, Horemheb strides over

dialogues.speaker: HOREMHEB
dialogues.text: What did the fool say?

dialogues.speaker: SINUHE
dialogues.text: (his astonishment being replaced by amused disgust) He said the god is coming.

dialogues.speaker: AKHNATON
dialogues.text: (an intense whisper staring toward the east) The god is coming! Sinuhe and Horemheb also look eastward.

dialogues.speaker: THE EAST
dialogues.text: The rim of the sun is just beginning to show over the horizon, flooding the world with golden light.

dialogues.speaker: SINUHE
dialogues.text: His god is Aton, the sun. He is a sun worshipper. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: AKHNATON
dialogues.text: (bows his head for prayer - simply but with intense emotion) Rise. Shine with splendor. Fill the world with your beauty so that we may rejoice. God, our father, creator of all things, great and small -- Overcome with the intensity of his emotion, Akhnaton pitc forward onto his face and lies on the sand quivering.

dialogues.speaker: HOREMHEB
dialogues.text: Now what ails him?

dialogues.speaker: SINUHE
dialogues.text: He has the holy sickness. (goes to Akhnaton) Bring water. After a look Horemheb goes to the chariot. Sinuhe stoops down by Akhnaton and rolls him over onto his back. The young man is unconscious.

dialogues.speaker: SINUHE
dialogues.text: (still rather amused) At least I can see that he doesn't swallow his tongue. He tears astripof linen from his clothing, rolls it and inserts it into Akhnaton's mouth. At the same time Horemheb returns from the chariot bringing a small stone flask of water bound with reeds, which he uncorks and hands to Sinuhe. Sinuhe dampens another strip of linen with water and washes the young man's forehead,

dialogues.speaker: HOREMHEB
dialogues.text: (with amused scorn) Look at him shiver! But at the same time he removes his cloak and spreade it over Akhnaton.

dialogues.speaker: HOREMHEB
dialogues.text: Even such a fool can't be left to die. Let's get him to the chariot. Ee stoops down to pick up the frail figure of the uncon- scious young man. At this instant -

dialogues.speaker: EIE'S VOICE
dialogues.text: (from nearby offscene - outraged) Holdt Startled, Sinuhe and Horemheb look over.  542 57 58 59 60 é1

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ele stands on the crest of a nearby hillock. At fifty- odd he is a tall, thin, stern man. He carries a staff and wears a costume ornamented with leopard skin, which denotes that he is a priest of very high rank. In a rage he strides down toward them, camera coming with him.

dialogues.speaker: EIE
dialogues.text: (accusingly) You laid hands on him! (arrives) Both of youl

dialogues.speaker: SINUHE
dialogues.text: {in explanation, astonished and angry) I am a physician --

dialogues.speaker: HOREMHEB
dialogues.text: (angry) Who is this loon? He cost us a lion} From nearby o.s. the brassy notes of a trumpet split the air. All look.

dialogues.speaker: PAST GROUP
dialogues.text: From just beyond the rise the sound of the trumpet is heard again, then over the rise there begins to appear a detachment of SOLDIERS carrying lances - a small detach- ment, there will be ten of them in all. Sinuhe and Horemheb look at each other in ewn greater astonishment.

dialogues.speaker: SINUHE
dialogues.text: What now? Horemheb sees that his team is threatening to bolt, runs to them.

dialogues.speaker: AT CHARIOT
dialogues.text: Horemheb seizes the bridles of his team of plunging horse and at the same time looks around at ~

dialogues.speaker: HILLOCK
dialogues.text: Following the detachment of soldiers comes a carrying- chair transported on the shoulders of six SLAVES. The chair is accompanied by a couple of PRIESTS of a lower rank than Ele and by a small group of COURTIERS of ob- viously high rank who carry ostrich fans with which they shield the occupant of the chair, who is Baketamon, at this time not yet Queen, but Princess.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At twenty-six, the Princess is a vision of beauty, but already cold and aloof. As she takes in the scene -  62 63 Sh. 65 66 19.

dialogues.speaker: AT CHARIOT
dialogues.text: Still holding his restive horses, Horemheb gapes at Baketamon with thunderstruck admiration. Sinuhe enters acene, almost as astonished as Horemheb.

dialogues.speaker: HOREMHEB
dialogues.text: Who is she?

dialogues.speaker: ENTIRE GROUP
dialogues.text: As the procession stops near the shrine and Elie hurries to the Princess, the latter first looks down at the pros- trate form of Akhnaton, then at Ele.

dialogues.speaker: BAKETAMON
dialogues.text: (to Ele, severely) Is this how you watch over my brother? (barest turning of her head indicates she takes in pair at chariot) Whe are these clods of dirt?

dialogues.speaker: AT CHARIOT
dialogues.text: Sinuhe and Horemheb are both staring, Horemheb agape with admiration, Sinuhe worried.

dialogues.speaker: EIE'S VOICE
dialogues.text: (accusingly) They have laid their hands on him}

dialogues.speaker: BAKETAMON
dialogues.text: Her only reaction is to survey the pair at the chariot coldly.

dialogues.speaker: BAKETAMON
dialogues.text: (sharply) Seize them!

dialogues.speaker: AT CHARIOT
dialogues.text: on the sand in front of Horemheb's team, a volley of lances plunk into the ground - a half dozen of them in rapid succession. The heads and thrashing forefeet of Horemheb's team are to be seen as the horses rear. The horses neigh with fright.

dialogues.speaker: CEREMONIAL PROCESSION
dialogues.text: Before we are made aware of the nature of the procession or even of the locale of this scene, we see these girls. The purpose of this opening scene is that of contrast from the violence of the ending of the previous scene to an atmosphere of gentle sweetness, These girls are dresse in flowing garments of virginal white, unornamented excep for thin girdles of stones. On bare feet they move with steps which are practically movements of a dance. On their fingers they wear little cymbals which they make reverberate with sweet music.

dialogues.speaker: ENTIRE COURT ROOM
dialogues.text: We have seen this room before, but not as it appears now, for while in the other instance the decorations were all warlike and violent, they are now gentle, with flowers and water fowl the prevailing motifs. The procession is at the far end of the room, too far for us to see to identify its participants, but we guess correctly that it is the entrance of Pharaoh, his family, and principal courtiers to the throne. There is a throng in the court room, all of whom are bowed to the floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Following the maidens, come some priests, including Ele, and courtiers, who carry fans to make a canopy over Pharaoh. We see that Pharaoh is none other than Akhnaton. Beside him walks his queen NEFERTITI, a young woman as beautiful and frail as he. They walk with their arms around each other's waist. Directly behind them walks the Princess Baketamon, At her side is Baketamon's mother THE QUEEN MOTHER TAIA, a swarthy-complexioned, evil and interesting old woman. In turn, come princes and prin- cesses of the royal household. Akhnaton carries the emblems of his office carelessly in his free hand and with them, with quiet reproof, he is gesturing those in the court room to get to their feet.

dialogues.speaker: AKENATON
dialogues.text: Will you never learn that we are all friends here?

dialogues.speaker: WITH MILITARY GUARD
dialogues.text: At the sound of Akhnaton's voice, Sinuhe raises his head sharply, but those who are getting to their feet all arou him block his view of the speaker. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: SINUBE
dialogues.text: (startled) Horemhebi That voice! Horemhebd is also staring with the intention of getting to his feet.

dialogues.speaker: A MILITARY GUARD
dialogues.text: (roughly) On your faces} There are four soldiers guarding Sinuhe and Horemheb with an under-officer whose rank would compare with that of a sergeant. It takes a prod of the sergeant's lance between his shoulder blades to get Horemheb to the floor. Sinuhe is already there but is alive with excitement and apprehension at what he fears he has discovered.

dialogues.speaker: AT THRONE
dialogues.text: Akhnaton and Nefertiti take their places on the double throne - she putting her arm sbout him and leying her face against his shoulder, As the royal family, includ- ing Baketamon and Taia, take their places to one side and slightly behind the throne, as courtiers, priests and officials take their places according to their rank -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: rush into the room, DAUGHTERS OF PHARAOH, the eldest seven, ranging down; one with a pet monkey, one leading a pet gazelle, the tiniest with a doll; accompanied by a tumbling DWARF, followed by a distracted NURSEMAID; rush to their parents.

dialogues.speaker: CHILD
dialogues.text: (screaming with joy) Great mama! Look!

dialogues.speaker: NEFERTITI
dialogues.text: (as any mother to child) Peace, peace ~ papa is occupied.

dialogues.speaker: AKENATON
dialogues.text: (laughing) Let them play. (to child) Show me!  73 7h 75 76 22.

dialogues.speaker: IN MIDST OF CROWD
dialogues.text: Again Sinuhe reacts at the sound of Akhnaton's voice. He doesn't raise his head this time but prods Horemheb with excitement and apprehension.

dialogues.speaker: SINUHE
dialogues.text: (whispers) . Horemheb! The one we called an idiot is Pharaoh!

dialogues.speaker: HOREMHEB
dialogues.text: (amazed) Then she igs Pharach's sister?! Sound of laughter from direction of throne.

dialogues.speaker: SINUHE
dialogues.text: Forget her and think of us!

dialogues.speaker: HOREMHEB
dialogues.text: (in continuing amazement) Pharaoh's sisterl

dialogues.speaker: SINUHE
dialogues.text: Don't you kmow the law? We touched himl We'll lose our heads for it!

dialogues.speaker: NEAR THRONE
dialogues.text: Over the laughter of those around him, he raps sharply on the floor with his staff.

dialogues.speaker: EIE
dialogues.text: (ringing command) The young man called Sinuhe will step forwardt

dialogues.speaker: SINUHE AND HOREMHEB
dialogues.text: Prodded by the Sergeant's lance, Sinuhe gets to his feet.

dialogues.speaker: SINUHE
dialogues.text: (succinetly) Farewell, my friend. Camera pans with him as he starts forward, the court laughing at something at the throne, parting to let him through. :

dialogues.speaker: DAY
dialogues.text: Now the source of the laughter is revealed. A daughter of Pharoah is making her monkey do tricks. The Dwarf, in turn, is imitating everything the monkey does. Akhnaton, engrossed in this play, is laughing aloud. His queen is (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 76 (Cont.) 77 78 smiling. His courtiers follow Pharaoh's lead, laughing also, The entrance of Sinuhe into scene is hardly no- ticed and seemingly not noticed at all by Akhnaton. Sinuhe throws himself on his face before the throne and intones the customary salutation.

dialogues.speaker: SINUHE
dialogues.text: Mighty Pharaoh, King of Upper and Lower Egypt, Living Forever and Ever ... Akhnaton turns his attention to him, lifts a hand which stops instantly the childish game and brings silence in the court.

dialogues.speaker: SINUEE
dialogues.text: (continuing) Divine God --

dialogues.speaker: AKHNATON
dialogues.text: (in a tone neither friend- ly nor unfriendly) You have feet, Sinuhe ~~ stand on them. Sinuhe looks up in astonishment. He scrambles to his feet but immediately bows his head contritely and respect fully.

dialogues.speaker: AKHNATON
dialogues.text: And look at me. Sinuhe raises his head and looks at him.

dialogues.speaker: AKHNATON
dialogues.text: His strange eyes seem to bore into Sinuhe.

dialogues.speaker: SINUHE
dialogues.text: He starts to open his mouth as if to say something - to make some defense - but remains silent.

dialogues.speaker: AKHNATON
dialogues.text: {his tone still im- personal) You are the son of Senmut, who is ealled The Just, who lives near the river docks and is a physician to the poor?

dialogues.speaker: SINUHE
dialogues.text: His foster son. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 79 (Cont.)

dialogues.speaker: AKHNATON
dialogues.text: Foster? What mean you?

dialogues.speaker: SINUHE
dialogues.text: That I was born an orphan.

dialogues.speaker: AKHNATON
dialogues.text: So? Relate this. (leans forward) SINUHE . I know only the little that I have myself been told. On the day of my birth, I was cast adrift on the Nile, as is the custom with unwanted chil- dren - in a boat no larger than a eradle, made of reeds, daubed with pitch, and tied with fowler's mots.

dialogues.speaker: BAKETAMON
dialogues.text: The old lady gives a start. She leans forward, her eyes glistening with a strange excitement, With an unconscious gesture she grips Baketamon's wrist, whose usual aloofnes is enough disturbed that she looks at her mother with curiosity.

dialogues.speaker: SINUHE'S VOICE
dialogues.text: (continuing from o.s.) My parentage is unknown. The woman I have learned to call my mother saw me floating past when she was at the river washing clothes and pulled me from the water, Because she was childless, she thanked the gods and carried me home - and she and Senmut have raised me as their own.

dialogues.speaker: TAIA
dialogues.text: (harshly) In what year?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Akhnaton turns to look at his mother in surprise. Others also, including Sinuhe.

dialogues.speaker: TAIA
dialogues.text: In what year were you born, to sur- vive thie river voyage? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: SINUHE
dialogues.text: In the same year as Pharaoh - so Itve been told.

dialogues.speaker: TATA
dialogues.text: In what season of that year?

dialogues.speaker: AKENATON
dialogues.text: Is there any point to these questions, Mama?

dialogues.speaker: TAIA
dialogues.text: (veiling her eyes) Curiosity only. : She seems to relax.

dialogues.speaker: AKHNATON
dialogues.text: (to Eie} Proceed, Call the other.

dialogues.speaker: EIE
dialogues.text: (raps with staff - commands sharply) The young man called Horemheb!

dialogues.speaker: TAIA AND BAKETAMON
dialogues.text: Though the queen mother has seemed to relax, in actual- ity she hasn't at all but continues to study Sinuhe. Un- eonsciously she still retains her grip on Baketamon's wrist and the latter has to forcibly remove her hand. Then Baketamon looks off in the direction from which she hears a buzz of excitement.

dialogues.speaker: FROM BAKETAMON'S PERSPECTIVE
dialogues.text: Horemheb is walking sturdily toward the throne. His bear- ing, his magnificent physique, cause a stir of interest, and especially from the women.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He walks like a soldier. At first his eyes are obviously directed toward the throne, then his look shifts in such a manner that we know he is looking at Baketamon.

dialogues.speaker: TAIA AND BAKETAMON
dialogues.text: Baketamon is well aware of Horemheb's look and her eyes brighten with an answering fire. Taia plucks at her sleeve.

dialogues.speaker: TAIA
dialogues.text: This young man they call Sinuhe -- (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 86 87 88 89 26. (Cont. ) : It 4s with a bit of a start that Baketamon comes enough to herself to look at her mother.

dialogues.speaker: TAIA
dialogues.text: Note his features! Baketamon glances toward Sinuhe at the throne but then immediately looks toward Horemheb again.

dialogues.speaker: THRONE
dialogues.text: As Horemheb arrives before the throne, he is still look- ing at Baketamon. Slowly he transfers his look from her to Akhnaton, He does not make the usual reverence but only looks steadily at the monarch, There is a buzz of excitement at this audacity.

dialogues.speaker: SINUHE AND HOREMHEB
dialogues.text: Sinuhe grows afraid for him - tries to signal him to make the reverence, but Horemheb doesn't see.

dialogues.speaker: HOREMEHEB
dialogues.text: Pharaoh is both god and man. May I speak to the man?

dialogues.speaker: DAY
dialogues.text: There is an additional buzz at this additional imperti- nence, If Akhnaton is surprised his inscrutable face doesn't show ith

dialogues.speaker: AKENATON
dialogues.text: {after a pause, with @ slight smile) Speak. Although Akhnation is smiling, it is by no means a friend ly smile; lurking in his amusement there seems to be also danger to Horemheb.

dialogues.speaker: HOREMHEB
dialogues.text: I am a graduate of the Military School and it is my wish to enter Pharaoh's service as a warrior. On the day of my birth a god in the form of the sa- ered Falcon perched on our roof, fore- telling my destiny - that I would one day rule over a great army and a great woman! (he looks over toward Baketamon) There are actual gasps at this audacity.  90 91 92 93 9h 27.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She stares intrigued at Horemheb.

dialogues.speaker: AT THRONE
dialogues.text: Akhnaton looks over toward Baketamon, back to Horemheb. As Sinuhe watches, nervous for Horemheb -

dialogues.speaker: AKENATON
dialogues.text: (with deceptive mild- ness) I have never heard of you until this day, Horemheb. Who are your parents? Was your father perhaps a commander for my father? The shot tells. Horemheb is suddenly possessed of great embarrassment.

dialogues.speaker: HOREMHEB
dialogues.text: My parents --- He glances at Baketamon, back again - remains silent,

dialogues.speaker: AKHNATON
dialogues.text: (with a dangerous smile) You were bold enough in speech before ~- speak now,

dialogues.speaker: HOREMHEB
dialogues.text: My parents were makers of cheese. There is a roar of laughter from all around. But Akhnaton doesn't laugh. Nor Horemheb, Sinuhe or Baketamon.

dialogues.speaker: HOREMHEB
dialogues.text: He turns his face toward Baketamon, no longer so proudly but with an appeal,

dialogues.speaker: BAKETAMON
dialogues.text: turns her face away from him, her interest in him dead, her pride insulted.

dialogues.speaker: THE THRONE
dialogues.text: Akhnaton glances from Baketamon to Horemheb once more.

dialogues.speaker: EIE
dialogues.text: (with as mich impa- tience as his respect for Akhnaton permits) May I proceed? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: AKENA TON
dialogues.text: Do.

dialogues.speaker: EIE
dialogues.text: Then first Sinuhe - step forward! Sinuhe takes a step or two forward. Eie impressively unrolls a large leather scroll,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All know the law. The sentence is death, Ele turns and signals into background,

dialogues.speaker: BACKGROUND TO THRONE
dialogues.text: An EXECUTIONER, a brawny fellow who carries a long sword, followed by AN ASSISTANT EXECUTIONER, who carries a large copper bowl, comes forward, takes his place near Sinuhe, the assistant placing the bowl on the floor in front of the throne. Onlookers are tense with suspense.

dialogues.speaker: EIE
dialogues.text: (announcing generally) And all have knowledge of the tradi- tion --- only in the sacred will of Pharach is it known whether the sword will fall with the edge -- He makes a gesture with his hand, holding it out perpen- dicularly, with fingers and thumb in a line. -- or the flat, He changes his hand to a horizontal position.

dialogues.speaker: SINUHE AND HOREMHEB
dialogues.text: Sinuhe turns, tries to smile at him bravely, Horemheb, reassuringly. Then Sinuhe looks openly et Akhnaton,

dialogues.speaker: SINUHE
dialogues.text: So let it be.

dialogues.speaker: AKHNATON
dialogues.text: studies Sinuhe, his look inscrutable.

dialogues.speaker: DAY
dialogues.text: Sinuhe kneels, bows his head forward over the bowl,  99 100 101 102 29.

dialogues.speaker: TAIA AND BAKETAMON
dialogues.text: Again the Queen Mother is possessed with intense excite- mont, leaning forward, eyes glistening, again uncon- sciously seizing Baketamon's wrist. The latter looks at her, wondering what possesses her.

dialogues.speaker: DAY
dialogues.text: Akhnaton nods at Executioner. The latter swings his sword high in an arc, eyes on Pharaoh. Only at the moment that the sword begins its descent does Akhnaton extend his han - horizontally. The Executioner checks the momentum of the sword, which comes to rest with the flat lightly touc ing Sinuhe's neck, There is an audible sound of approval from the onlookers.

dialogues.speaker: SINUHE
dialogues.text: looks up at Akhnaton as one delivered from the dead,

dialogues.speaker: DAY
dialogues.text: Akhnaton smiles, In b.g., Taia relaxes her grip on Baketamon's wrist, smilingly also, but strangely.

dialogues.speaker: AKHNATON
dialogues.text: As Sinuhe you are dead, Rise as a newborn man. Sinuhe gets to his feet, his face alight. Looking always at Akhnaton he extends a hand behind him - Horemheb grasp it.

dialogues.speaker: AKHNATON
dialogues.text: With your new life I give you a new name which shall be written in Pharaoh's Golden Book, which shall be "He Who Is Alone," in consequence or your orphan birth and journey down the river. He tosses down to Sinuhe an "honor" in the form of a jeweled "chain" (necklace), which Sinuhe in his intense excitement almost fails to catch. Akhnation is now smiling openly, even with affection, at Sinuhe. He speaks again, and with each phrase tosses down another jeweled, golden honor, in the form of a necklace, a bracelet, a scarab --

dialogues.speaker: AKHNATON
dialogues.text: Never will I forget that you laid your hands on me in peeling: I make you physician to my household - and may God prosper you, (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 102 (Cont.) 103 10h, 105 106 - until Sinuhe, overwhelmed, cannot believe his good fortune, There is a scene of joy and approval from all, The Dwarf and the monkey are cutting capers. Even Eie is smiling, until -

dialogues.speaker: EIE
dialogues.text: (cutting through) Horemheb! Stand forward! Instantly all sound ceases. Sinuhe's joy is quenched, as he realizes that in his personal joy he has forgotten his friend.

dialogues.speaker: SINUHE AND HOREMHEB
dialogues.text: as Sinuhe looks at him, asking pardon.

dialogues.speaker: HOREMHEB
dialogues.text: (smiles a touch wryly) I fear that this sword and my neck will have a passing acquaintance,

dialogues.speaker: DAY
dialogues.text: as Horemheb steps forward, having decided at any event to die like a soldier should,

dialogues.speaker: EIE
dialogues.text: (routinely) All kmow the law - the sentence is death - in the will of Pharaoh --

dialogues.speaker: AKHENATON
dialogues.text: (interrupts) One moment, High Priest. All look with surprise toward the throne.

dialogues.speaker: AKENATON
dialogues.text: In this case I wish the will of my sister Baketamon to guide the sword. He looks rather impishly at Baketamon. All gasp and look toward her,

dialogues.speaker: BAKETAMON
dialogues.text: at first looks only very startled at Akhnaton.

dialogues.speaker: S BETWEEN HOREMHEB AND BAKETAMON
dialogues.text: He looks with hope toward her. She looks slowly from Akhnaton to Horemheb. Slowly a look of haughty pride, of disdain, even a amile of derision shows on her face. Horemheb reads what is so obviously her decision. As he starts to kneel -  107 108 109 110 lil lie 31.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as Horemheb, kmeeling, extends his neck, there is a buzz in courtroom and -

dialogues.speaker: A VOICE
dialogues.text: (heard from crowd, unidentified) Pity him. Sinuhe is tense, afraid. The Executioner moves into a position from which he can watch for Baketamon's signal. She is smiling cruelly. She nods. The Executioner swings high the sword and at the same time Baketamon extends her hand <- vertical. Only as the Executioner 1s about to start his downward swing does she change her mind and make the gesture horizontal. There is a sound from the crowd - excitement only as the flat of sword comes to rest lightly on Horemheb's neck.

dialogues.speaker: SINUHE
dialogues.text: Sinuhe breathes a deep breath of relief.

dialogues.speaker: AKHNATON
dialogues.text: looks curiously toward Baketamon, clearly greatly sur- prised.

dialogues.speaker: HOREMHEB
dialogues.text: raises his head slowly to look at Baketamon, not so much in gratitude as in a sort of triumph.

dialogues.speaker: BAKETAMON
dialogues.text: lowers her hand, which until this moment she has held in the gesture of clemency. But there's no clemency in her expression. There is still only derision.

dialogues.speaker: DAY
dialogues.text: Horemheb gets to his feet, unbidden by Pharaoh. He con- tinues to look only at Baketamon during all that follows. Akhnaton looks at Horemhsb. There's no liking in his look. He shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: AKBNATON
dialogues.text: My sister having shown the way, Pharaoh but can follow -- I grant you your wish, Horemheb - appoint you an officer in the Palace Guard. He tosses down a jeweled collar which strikes against Horemheb and falls unheeded by him to the floor. Sinuhe, startled, rushes to pick it up. Akhnaton smiles. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: AKENATON
dialogues.text: I remember that though you thought me a fool you spread your cloak on me when I shivered. He tosses down several more honors but with the manner of tossing them away rather than bestowing. These like the first fall unheeded to the floor. There is conster- nation in the courtroom and Sinuhe frantically gathers the honors to which Horemheb pays no heed.

dialogues.speaker: AKENATON
dialogues.text: God has commanded me to love all men and so I will try to love you.

dialogues.speaker: BAKETAMON AND TAIA
dialogues.text: Baketamon turns to Taia, her derisive expression altered only by a more derisive smile.

dialogues.speaker: BAKETAMON
dialogues.text: A cheese maker!

dialogues.speaker: AND HOREMHEB
dialogues.text: There are a number of drinking places along this part of the street and the atmosphere is rather gay. Light shines from a tall column of a street lamp, -an open flame. Musi comes from some interior - probably ‘Syrian music, Some soldiers with girls - a mixed crowd -- someone passing in a carrying chair with runners going ahead shouting, "Make wayi” 2... Sinuhe and Horemhebd are slanting across the street towar an inn above the entrance gate of which is displayed 4 huge dried crocodile which gives the place its name, "The Crocodile's Tail." Wearing all the honors which Akhnaton has this day bestowed on them they have set out to make a night of it - but only Sinuhe is in the mood, Horemheb being rather glum.

dialogues.speaker: HOREMHEB
dialogues.text: She commanded our arrest! She gave the signal which saved my life! When I tried to thank her, she all but spat at me! Who can understand a woman!

dialogues.speaker: SINUEE
dialogues.text: (laughs) If we could understand them, we might not love them.

dialogues.speaker: HOREMHEB
dialogues.text: (with a trace of bitterness) Easy enough for you to talk ~ your aim is on a tavern girl.

dialogues.speaker: SINUHE
dialogues.text: How little you know her. Half my trouble comes from being half in love. When a man gives his heart he gives his power - a woman is taken in com- pletely only by a man who does not believe a word he tells her.

dialogues.speaker: HOREMHEB
dialogues.text: (scoffing, but lighten- ine to better humor) Listen to him who has yet to seduce his first slave girl! Sinuhe laughs, agreeing; hugs Horemheb's arm.

dialogues.speaker: SINUHE
dialogues.text: But tonight will be another story. The sweet little one says no to a poor physician - (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 542 3h. 114 (Cont. ) 115 116 SINUHE (Cont. ) (jestingly displaying jewelry = but who can resist the glories of Fharaoh's physician? Laughing, they go through gate.

dialogues.speaker: MERCHANTS
dialogues.text: This is a corridor - (could be a small courtyard) - which leads to the principal room of the Inn. There may be wine jugs stored here. Two MERCHANTS are leaving the. Inn en route to street, followed by Kaptah, a slave, dressed in rags, possessed of one good eye and one blind eye, ove the socket of which he wears a dirty patch - and who is making a fervent "pitch" to sell himself

dialogues.speaker: KAPTAH
dialogues.text: Great merchants, buy me at a bargain} Feed me on crusts of bread and water! Beat me whenever it pleases youl Failing with them as they go out into street, Kaptah sees Sinuhe and Horemheb, who have entered, reverses himself, follows them, attaches himself to Sinuhe.

dialogues.speaker: KAPTAH
dialogues.text: Noble lord, beloved of Pharaoh, let me be your slave and dog! Paying no heed to Kaptah -

dialogues.speaker: SINUHE
dialogues.text: (to Horemheb, hiding Pharaoh's jewelry in cloak) Hide our glitter until she comes to the table - take her by surprise! Horemheb hides his jewelry, like Sinuhe; they go in; Kapteah follows.

dialogues.speaker: CUSTOMERS AND SERVING GIRLS
dialogues.text: It is a tavern for the middle classes, fairly well patron ized, customers being served by girls. Walls are decorate with trophies from far places, including savages! weapons As Sinuhe and Horemheb come in, Sinuhe, looking for some- one pe does not yet see, Kaptah attached to Sinuhe like a eech - (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: KAPTAH
dialogues.text: Take note that I have only one eye, Physician! A blemish? - nay! - with it I shall make your fortune when I go into the streets proclaiming that formerly I was totally blind until your skill restored half my sight! Conscious of Kaptah only as a vague disturbance, Sinhue tosses back to him a few coppers, alms for a beggar, to get rid of him. Kaptah scrambles for them.

dialogues.speaker: ACROSS ROOM
dialogues.text: a serving girl, who turns from something she is doing, looks across the room at -

dialogues.speaker: NIGHT
dialogues.text: The two friends take their places at a secluded table.

dialogues.speaker: MERIT
dialogues.text: MERIT is a girl of about Sinuhe's age. She wears a simple linen dress, a linen headpiece, a silver ring in one ear, silver bangles on her wrists. By character she is self- possessed, honest, frank, possessed of a sharp tongue, whether used for humor or seriousness. Her face is comely her eyes warm and living, and always have a mingling of a smile and sorrow in them. Just now - as she looks over at Sinuhe - it seems that it is the sorrow which becomes accentuated,

dialogues.speaker: KAPTAH
dialogues.text: The slave, having gathered the last of the coppers, sits on floor near Sinuhe, attached even more firmly to him - an act which Horemheb notes, but not Sinuhe, who has just caught sight of Merit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seeing Sinuhe's eyes on her, she turns away, places a wine jug and two drinking bowls on a copper platter, goes out of scene toward table with them.

dialogues.speaker: AT TABLE
dialogues.text: Seeing Merit coming, Sinuhe, taking even more care to hid Pharach's jewelry, smiles with eager anticipation. Horemheb, because of his own unhappiness, shares only par of Sinuhe's feelings. The slave watches with his one eye on Sinuhe. When Merit enters scene, Sinuhe's expression (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 122 (Cont. } changes to astonishment - for she doesn't so much as look at him, nor at Horemheb, but approaches the table as to strangers, her eyes on the tray, her mind apparently only on what she is doing. In this manner she begins to serve the wine. Sinuhe stares at her. Deciding that this must be some game she has invented out of caprice, he opens hi cloak with a gesture which he thinks she cannot miss, dis playing Pharach's honors. Horemheb, alerted, sensing some thing, does the same. Not a reaction from Merit, her eyes on table and what she is doing. In consternation, sure now that this is a deliberate caprice, Sinuhe is put to the necessity of offering -

dialogues.speaker: SINUHE
dialogues.text: Happy is the loveliness of the night. No response. In consternation Sinuhe throws a glance at Horemheb. Merit, finished with her business with the wine in a tone which plainly says that it is only the customar phrase of every serving girl to any customer -

dialogues.speaker: MERIT
dialogues.text: May it benefit you. - turns to go. Bewildered, Sinuhe can do nothing except finally to reach out and grab her skirt to stop her.

dialogues.speaker: SINUHE
dialogues.text: Merit! She stops, nothing more, refusing to resist the pressure of his hold on her clothing, but not making a move to turn.

dialogues.speaker: SINUHE
dialogues.text: What foolishness is this?

dialogues.speaker: MERIT
dialogues.text: Foolishness? It is your usual wine, my lord. If you are not pleased ~~

dialogues.speaker: SINUHE
dialogues.text: Merit! Stop it! Itve come to bring the most wonderful tidings - (getting angry) - which you could see if you were not blind!

dialogues.speaker: MERIT
dialogues.text: (interrupting, a touch sharply) Your fame has arrived before you, physician to the King of Egypt. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 122 (Gont.1) He stares at her with mouth open. Horemheb is becoming amused at Sinuhe's discomfiture - misery loving company. Kaptah's single eye is alertly taking in everything be- tween the girl and his chosen master.

dialogues.speaker: SINUHE
dialogues.text: Ie that all you have to say?

dialogues.speaker: MERIT
dialogues.text: No. I also have to say that as you sit there clutching my skirt, you have the manners of a green boy who wishes to approach a serving girl. He drops her skirt like a live coal, throws a look at Horemheb. Horemheb laughs. Sinuhe is stung. He looks back, sees that Merit has gone. He jumps up and, camera moving with him, follows her, grabs her, whirls her around, camera putting them alone in close shot.

dialogues.speaker: SINUHE
dialogues.text: Is this some game?

dialogues.speaker: MERIT
dialogues.text: (seriously) No, Sinuhe, I am not playing.

dialogues.speaker: SINUHE
dialogues.text: (holding her shoulders, even shaking her) For years have we not said that some day the hand of fortune might reach down, lift me from poverty and bring us our dreams?

dialogues.speaker: MERIT
dialogues.text: (smiles, but sadly) For you I am happy. For myself --- why should I be happy for something which will separate us?

dialogues.speaker: SINUHE
dialogues.text: Separate? --

dialogues.speaker: MERIT
dialogues.text: (with bitterness) The stairway in Pharaoh's palace does not lead to the servants! quarters, my lord. Sinuhe stares at her a moment, then bursts into laughter.

dialogues.speaker: SINUHE
dialogues.text: Stop it, Merit -- take off your apron -- (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 122 (Cont.2) 38. SINUHE (Cont. ) (tries to remove it; she stops him) A boat waits on the river with wine and music.

dialogues.speaker: MERIT
dialogues.text: (stubbornly) No.

dialogues.speaker: SINUHE
dialogues.text: (stares again) I cannot understand you.

dialogues.speaker: MERIT
dialogues.text: Can't you? (cuttingly) My name is Merit, and this is a decent tavern, and I am not so far from being innocent - as you should know!

dialogues.speaker: SINUHE
dialogues.text: (takes her in his arms, caresses) But surely you know how I feel -- ?

dialogues.speaker: MERIT
dialogues.text: (for the first time furious) Exactly. (twists out of his arms) And what you want of me} (slaps his face) And for what you want, I recommend that you go elsewhere!)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: from which Horemheb and Kapteh have been taking it all in

dialogues.speaker: KAPTAH
dialogues.text: (jumps up eagerly) I know just the place, Master! There is a wondrous party tonight = right next door to the Temple of the Goddess of Love}

dialogues.speaker: MERIT
dialogues.text: (now thoroughly angry) Why don't you gol (with sarcasm) I'm sure that Pharaoh's physician would be most welcome! (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: HOREMHEB
dialogues.text: (laughs) Sounds ideal.

dialogues.speaker: MERIT
dialogues.text: And take your friend with you!

dialogues.speaker: HOREMHEB
dialogues.text: Why not?

dialogues.speaker: SINUHE
dialogues.text: (goaded from both sides, agrees) Yesi Why not? (with angry humor) She is a better physician than I am -- as a cure for one woman she pre- scribes another)

dialogues.speaker: MERIT
dialogues.text: {in such a fury she is near tears) Just go there] - and then dare ever to come back to me}

dialogues.speaker: KAPTAH
dialogues.text: (eagerly) Shall I hire a carrying chair for my lord?

dialogues.speaker: SINUHE
dialogues.text: (to Horemheb) Who is he?

dialogues.speaker: HOREMHEB
dialogues.text: (laughs) Your slave -- you bought him.

dialogues.speaker: SINUHE
dialogues.text: Did I? (to Kaptah, accepting him, too) Hire a chair! Kaptah scoots out toward door. Horemheb gets up, all ready. Sinuhe turns back for a last thing to Merit.

dialogues.speaker: SINURE
dialogues.text: And may your precious virtue warm you like a woolen blanket on cold winter nights? As she watches -  52 12h 125 ko.

dialogues.speaker: FROM MERIT'S PERSPECTIVE
dialogues.text: march toward the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: looks after Sinuhe. Her anger turns to regret, Tears fill her eyes.

dialogues.speaker: A CAT
dialogues.text: General description of setting: We are in a smart city house in which a party is in progress (see illustration WAT'L GEOGRAPHIC Oct. 1941 p 505). There is food, a buffet table heaped with it, with fruits and flowers. There are flowers everywhere -- tubs of growing plants and baskets arranged cleverly with flowers, fruits and vegetables. Alli of the guests wear flowers, garlands around their necks and single blossoms in their head- dresses -- many of the guests carry single blossoms in their hands, Slaves carry around wine vases draped with flowers - and even the tall pink colums which support the ceiling of this two-storied hall terminate with carv- ings representing opening lotus blooms. All of this is general description which is to be fully disclosed only as we go along, for scene opens on a close shot of Nefer' CAT. The cat wears a colored collar which ts studded with gems and it is tethered to the leg of an armehair, which chair is on a slightly raised dais and is decorated with symbol of the cat-headed goddess, Bast. There is a woman seated in the chair but of her we see only a pair of beautiful legs beneath a sheer linen garment with jeweled anklets above jeweled sandals. The cat is rubbing against the legs. In direct b.g., we have a more or less clear suggestion of some DANCING GIRLS who move with sensuous, feline grace to o.s. music of harp, lyre, guitar, tam bourine, pipes and flutes. As the cat looks o.s., its attention apparently arrested by something -

dialogues.speaker: SINUHE AND HOREMHEB
dialogues.text: Again the scene contains the suggestion of the dancing girls along one side of screen, and we may also see at least a portion of the ORCHESTRA the members of which, like the dancing girls, are slave girls - but the focus of attention is the ‘door through which Sinuhe and Horemhebd enter. They come in like strangers arriving in unfamiliar surroundings. By entrance slave SERVANTS, both men and women, enter to them, stoop, remove their sandals and begin to wash their feet in rich bowls.

dialogues.speaker: SINUHE AND HOREMHEB
dialogues.text: look around and then look at each other as if to say, “This ig not so bad." Of the two Horemheb is the more at ease, for Sinuhe still is uncomfortable as a result of his quarrel with Merit.  129 130 131

dialogues.speaker: THE CAT
dialogues.text: Almost immediately a pair of arms decked with jewelry reach down into scene, take up the cat, and we see WEFER, She is very beautiful, with an experienced look about her. Her hair is dyed blue, and is sprinkled with gold and silver powder. She wears much red jowelry. Her eyebrows are blackened and beneath her eyes is painte @ green shadow. But greener than all green are her eyes themselves. Holding the cat on her lap, stroking it, she looks off at -

dialogues.speaker: HOREMHEB
dialogues.text: The slaves have completed washing the guests' feet and as they replace their sandals and rise a LADY enters scene. She is very attractive, wears a garland around her neck and carries another. This she puts around the neek of Horemheb who is nearest her and -

dialogues.speaker: LADY
dialogues.text: > (smiling invitingly) Come? She offers her left hand. Horemheb grins back at Sinuhe, takes the lady's hand and allows himself to be led o.s. Sinuhe smiles after him until he feels a garland of flowers slipped around his own neck, turns and sees that a 2ND LADY is smiling at him and offering her hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come? Suddenly Sinuhe finds himself embarrassed and realizes that the impulse which has brought him here with Horemheb will not mecessarily carry him farther.

dialogues.speaker: SINUHE
dialogues.text: (mutters, shaking his head) You will pardon ... He manages to convey with some gestures that he has some business with someone over there, moves away, edging along the wall.

dialogues.speaker: NEFER
dialogues.text: watches him, her interest piqued. Then with a gesture of her hand she swmmons TWO NEGROES, great black giants who stand guard behind her chair. They spring forward. One of them carries an ebony box. Nefer looks away from Sinuhe long enough to open the box, select a modest piece of jewelry which she tosses off to -  132 133 13h 135 136 137 43.

dialogues.speaker: PAST DANCING GIRLS TO NEFER
dialogues.text: The leader of the girls catches the bauble. Instantly the dancing and the music stop. The leader bows and the dancers run away. Nefer turns to look back at Sinuhe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He moves among the merrymakers trying to look as incon- spicuous as possible. Two slaves enter scene from the opposite direction carrying an image of the god, Osiris, & small mummy-image on a decorated bier, accompanied by a BUTLER who is saying to one and all, and to Sinuhe, the customary -

dialogues.speaker: BUTLER
dialogues.text: Eat, drink and be joyful - for no one knows what tomorrow will bring. The image is followed by girl slaves who bear cakes and others who bear wine.

dialogues.speaker: A GIRL SLAVE
dialogues.text: (to Sinuhe) Honey cakes, my lord? Painfully aware of being an uninvited guest, Sinuhe never theless takes a honey cake.

dialogues.speaker: SLAVE GIRL
dialogues.text: Wine, my lord? Thus pressed, Sinuhe takes a glass of wine and, with the goblet in his hand, chances to look up and see -

dialogues.speaker: FROM SINUHE'S PERSPECTIVE
dialogues.text: is looking directly at him.

dialogues.speaker: SINUHE
dialogues.text: is struck by two things simultaneously: a feeling that this is the most beautiful woman he has ever beheld, and a sharp guilt that he is uninvited here. He turns away, drinks the wine at a gulp, puts the goblet on the tray of the slave who is just going away and with this same movement slips out of sight behind some guests.

dialogues.speaker: NEFER
dialogues.text: smiles, She boosts the cat off her lap. Turns and signals to a HARPIST in b.g.

dialogues.speaker: HARPIST
dialogues.text: who strums his instrument and begins to play.  138 139 5a uy.

dialogues.speaker: AT A SIDE WALL NEAR NEFER
dialogues.text: is pretending to be interested in a mural on the wall. It is a rather remarkable mural, Cretan in origin, which shows the use of trained cats for stalking game. Sinuhe feels something rubbing against his leg and looks down.

dialogues.speaker: NEFER'S CAT AND SINUHE
dialogues.text: The cat is rubbing against Sinuhe's leg. Sinuhe stoops down into scene, strokes the cat, glad to have something to do. Then, when he sees that the cat's leash is being tightened and that the cat is being pulled away, he looks Up.

dialogues.speaker: PAST SINUHE TO NEFER
dialogues.text: As he stares at her, he feels that although she 1s not smiling at all, her business of drawing the cat toward her conveys an invitation.

dialogues.speaker: SINUHE AND NEFER
dialogues.text: as he follows the cat, as if drawn by ea magnet, to her.

dialogues.speaker: SINUHE
dialogues.text: (somewhat awkwardly) Is this your home?

dialogues.speaker: NEFER
dialogues.text: This is my home and these are my guests.

dialogues.speaker: SINUHE
dialogues.text: Then it is to you I must apologize --

dialogues.speaker: NEFER
dialogues.text: Oh?

dialogues.speaker: SINUHE
dialogues.text: ~ for being here. I came because of my friend - who is miserable in love ... (starts to remove garland of flowers) I'll leave, She reaches out and takes one of his hands to prevent his taking off the flowers. At the same time -

dialogues.speaker: NEFER
dialogues.text: That officer? She slowly turns her head and looks across the room.  142 143 4s.

dialogues.speaker: ACROSS ROOM
dialogues.text: are seated together drinking wine, From her garland the Lady takes a blossom, hands it to Horemheb.

dialogues.speaker: SINUHE AND NEFER
dialogues.text: She turns to him, finds that he is looking at her in a manner which plainly says that he has not taken his eyes off her. Her hand is still resting on his in the gesture she used to prevent his removing the garland of flowers. After a long pause -

dialogues.speaker: NEFER
dialogues.text: (with a light jest) Have you never seen a woman?

dialogues.speaker: SINURE
dialogues.text: Hundreds -- in the state the gods created them-- I am a doctor. She slowly takes away her hand.

dialogues.speaker: SINUHE
dialogues.text: But I have never seen a woman like you.

dialogues.speaker: NEFER
dialogues.text: (pleased) Oh?

dialogues.speaker: SINUHE
dialogues.text: Your eyes are greener than the Nile in summer -- what are you called?

dialogues.speaker: NEFER
dialogues.text: In their foolishness men give me the name which means beautiful.

dialogues.speaker: . SINUHE
dialogues.text: Kefer. {after a pause) Goodnight. (starts away)

dialogues.speaker: NEFER
dialogues.text: Why do you go? He stops and looks at her frankly.

dialogues.speaker: SINUHE
dialogues.text: Because men bring you rich gifts for as little as a smile and I am only a poor physician. Because ... you will laugh et me ... I have never looked at any woman except with the eyes of a doctor. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sh2 143 (Cont.) 1s

dialogues.speaker: NEFPER
dialogues.text: (her eyes flicker, she smiles) Can this be trues?

dialogues.speaker: SINUHE
dialogues.text: (shakes his head) In the Temple School it was forbidden. Since ... Her eyes have a different look, are glistening with a veiled but deep excitement.

dialogues.speaker: NEFER
dialogues.text: Of all the gifts that a man can bring to a woman which is the only one which is above all price?

dialogues.speaker: SINUHE
dialogues.text: I cannot say.

dialogues.speaker: NEPER
dialogues.text: His innocence, of course - which he can give only once. (after a long pause) Late at night my garden is beautiful by the lotus pool. As he makes a move she turns away - to greet a guest who enters -- a man whe obviously is a RICH MERCHANT, to whom she extends both her hands, not looking any more at Sinuh

dialogues.speaker: SINUHE
dialogues.text: locks at her, his pulses pounding.

dialogues.speaker: NIGHT
dialogues.text: Shot begins on her. Lying on a couch of mats by the lotus pool, she plays with her cat. As camera pulis back to include Sinuhe, seated by her, hypnotized - (lightly) Do you know why the goddess of love is portrayed as a cat? (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: SINUHE
dialogues.text: (shakes his head) Nor do I care. (earnestly) Nefer - listen! (hands go to Pharaoh's chains around his neck) All of value I possess was given me by Pharaoh, which is not right I give away -- (1s taking off chains)

dialogues.speaker: NEFER
dialogues.text: (puts her hand on his to stop him) What you must think of me! I have asked for nothing. (rests his hand, in her hand, on her stomach as if by accident) But first you shall hear why a passion is like a cat and why a woman, too, is like a cat - for both have claws which can rip and tear into your heart, and both can torment their prey. I tell you this because I would be honest with you. Leave me now - (lightly) - or you may live to forever regret it.

dialogues.speaker: SINUEE
dialogues.text: You know I can't leave! She sighs a little as if weary of the game, NEFER © So be it then. As she pushes the cat, makes it run away -

dialogues.speaker: EXT, NEFER'S HOUSE
dialogues.text: The street is deserted. Sinuhe comes out of Nefer's gate - walks away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At first we see only Merit. She is sweeping the floor with a rush broom, Actually she is using the broom more as a weapon than a cleaning instrument, for she is very angry, and is saying -

dialogues.speaker: MERIT
dialogues.text: What business is it of mine where he spends his time! As camera movement discloses Kaptah who, very distressed, is pleading with her.

dialogues.speaker: KAPTAH
dialogues.text: This morning he bade me send away all his patients to other doctors! When I tried to talk with him, he beat me! He sent for a barber and had himself anointed with sweet-smelling oils! He ordered a chair, so that he would arrive at her house with his feet un- soiled with dust! He is maddened!

dialogues.speaker: MERIT
dialogues.text: struggling with herself, about to make another sharp retort, suddenly goes bleak.

dialogues.speaker: MERIT
dialogues.text: (quietly) Bring him to me if you can,

dialogues.speaker: NEFER
dialogues.text: She is being given a bath by a SLAVE MAID ~ partially visible ~ who pours buckets of warm water over her. The water is washing the blue dye out of her hair, showing its natural color. Somewhere in the house muted music is to be heard, to which Nefer is humming - until she looks over and is reminded of the presence of someone O.8., and little thought wrinkles cross her brow.

dialogues.speaker: NEAR BATH
dialogues.text: Seated on a stool, is looking toward her, devouring her hungrily with his eyes. He is distracted by the passing of a WOMAN SLAVE.

dialogues.speaker: GENERAL SCENE
dialogues.text: Bathing is no private function with Nefer. In addition to Sinuhe and the slave maid there are present her customary ( CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ho. 151 (Cont.) Negro guards, one holding her ever present jewelry box, and a pet dwarf, who is teasing Nefer's cat. On two e sides of her bath trough there is an L-shaped partition almost shoulder-high - which blocks a complete view of her to both camera and Sinuhe. The woman slave who has entered carries a small scroll, some message, which she hands to Nefer. WNefer unrolis it, begins to read.

dialogues.speaker: MESSAGE
dialogues.text: In Egyptian hieroglyphics - a short message. Water from Nefer's bath, colored blue from her hair dye, is washing away the ink on the papyrus, making the message disappear

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Her eyes flicker with secret satisfaction before she tosses away the parchment. She looks toward Sinuhe and -

dialogues.speaker: NEFER
dialogues.text: (carefully light) Is it malice or stupidity that brings you here today, Sinuhe? He is greatly surprised.

dialogues.speaker: NEFER
dialogues.text: What do you want? His eyes flicker.

dialogues.speaker: NEFER
