dialogues.text: Was I not generous with you? But yesterday was yesterday and today is today. I am a woman who lives alone and must see to the future - (with mockery) - when your love will have cooled and only wolves are at my door -- (with careless frankness ) - and today a merchant has arrived from Babylon -- Sinuhe reacts with a start of anger, listens incredulousl to -

dialogues.speaker: NEFER
dialogues.text: - with an anklet of wondrous rubies red as blood - which I think tomorrow can be mine. Sinuhe's face flushes and hardens with anger.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: she 50. 153 (Cont.)

dialogues.speaker: NEFER
dialogues.text: (with a bite) Now be off. He stubbornly looks at her. She gives him time to think about it; with her manner of light coldness orders her maid by gesture to cease pouring water and wrap her nakedness in linen.

dialogues.speaker: SINUHE
dialogues.text: still looks stubborn. Slowly he comes to a decision. He gestures to someone off and the Negro with the ebony box enters scene, his face a cynical mask. Hating to do it, Sinuhe strips his person of the honors Akhnaton gave him and begins dropping them one by one into the box.

dialogues.speaker: WEFER
dialogues.text: notes this - not showing him that she notes it - and with a secret expression which is a small part satisfaction and most part cynical amusement.

dialogues.speaker: SINUHE
dialogues.text: looks at her as if to say that this is his answer to the merchant with the ruby anklet, for this is his all.

dialogues.speaker: DAY
dialogues.text: Nefer walks lightly to him. Her linen wrapper clings to her wet body. She smiles at him. For a moment she rests her hand on his hair. He smiles, thinking all is well.

dialogues.speaker: NEFER
dialogues.text: Why must all men be such liars and deceivers? As his look changes to astonishment she turns away and walks lightly to her anointing room. At the door she stops, turns.

dialogues.speaker: NEFER
dialogues.text: Confess that you are not altogether as poor as you pretend. I believe you have a house, a slave and valuable instruments of fine copper and stone.

dialogues.speaker: SINUHE
dialogues.text: (in violent protest) I need these! I ama doctor! She shrugs, goes into the anointing room as if she has dr the subject. She puts aside her linen wrapper and lies on table - partially out of view. A slave maid already waits there for her and is seen to begin to anoint her body wit oil.  she 158 159 160 Si.

dialogues.speaker: SINUHE
dialogues.text: 4s a victim of a struggle between anger, resentment and desire,

dialogues.speaker: THE ANOINTING TABLE
dialogues.text: exchange for a moment a secret knowing look, before -

dialogues.speaker: NEFER
dialogues.text: (carelessly calling out to Sinuhe) I ask for nothing.

dialogues.speaker: STUDENTS, KAPTAH
dialogues.text: Sinuhe is speaking as scene opens.

dialogues.speaker: SINUHE
dialogues.text: Fellow physicians and students of the House of Life, rejoice that we are Egyptians, foremost in the world in the science of healing. We know the skill of curing blindness with a needle - the use of splints for broken bones - of salves to prevent wounds from festering - of drugs to induce false sleep so that men do not feel pain. Camera has pulled back to include the whole scene. Sinuhe is about to give a demonstration before fellow physicians and students. He is being assisted by another PHYSICIAN. Kaptah squats on the ground near him, eyeing his master with anxious distress. Sinuhe's thoughts are not with what he is saying; his thoughts are with Nefer.

dialogues.speaker: SINUHE
dialogues.text: (proceeding with difficulty) Honored am I to have been asked to demonstrate my specialty, the unique art of boring skulls. Sitting in a chair with a linen sheet draped around him is the PATIENT on whom the demonstration is to be given. He is rolling his head and moaning with pain,

dialogues.speaker: SINUHE
dialogues.text: This man suffers with evil spirits in the head. (to patient) Where does it pain most? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 160 (Cont.)

dialogues.speaker: PATIENT
dialogues.text: (groans) Everywhere!

dialogues.speaker: SINUHE
dialogues.text: (to assisting physician - holding out hand) My instrument ~ (with sudden unconscious outburst) I cannot do without my instruments! At the shocked look from assisting physician Sinuhe reali what he has said. He hesitates.

dialogues.speaker: SINUHE
dialogues.text: (murmurs ) You will pardon - He goes to the patient and with a small hammer which he has taken from the assisting physician he taps the patient's head in various places. When he hits a certain spot the man screams.

dialogues.speaker: SINUHE
dialogues.text: (continuing with difficulty) In this spot beneath the skull there is an ugly growth. tte patient, hand~ ing him cup} Drink this and in a moment you will be without pain. Sinuhe is beginning to hear music, on sound track, the same he heard when last with Nefer, With a hand which trembles he takes a boring instrument from the assisting physician.

dialogues.speaker: SINUHE
dialogues.text: (continuing with greater difficulty) I shall cut away a piece of bone from this man's skull, remove the growth, replace the bone with a disc of silver -- (suddenly to assistant physician) Finish for me! To the astonishment of all he rushes away and out of the courtyard.

dialogues.speaker: KAPTAH
dialogues.text: Sinuhe is hurrying toward the gate carrying a scroll.

dialogues.speaker: KAPTAH
dialogues.text: (desperately pleading) Do not cast me off, master!

dialogues.speaker: SINUHE
dialogues.text: (very angry) I am no longer your master!

dialogues.speaker: KAPTAH
dialogues.text: (seizes Sinuhe's clothing) Come with me to the Inn! I beg you! Sinuhe stops and with great anger raises his arm to strik the slave, but seeing that Kaptah patiently awaits the blow, changes his mind and lowers his arm. About to go on toward gate he stops again when he sees -

dialogues.speaker: FROM SINUHE'S PERSPECTIVE TOWARD GATE
dialogues.text: A rich carrying chair awaits before the gate, attended by SLAVES and RUNNERS. Out of Nefer's gate, with all the air of a man who is satisfied, comes an obviously wealthy BABYLONIAN MERCHANT. It is to be noted - for future reference - that in his headdress he wears a‘marvelous diamond. As he allows his servants to help him into the chair -

dialogues.speaker: SINUHE
dialogues.text: guessing at the implication, becomes at once angry and desperate, runs to the gate. Nefer's GATEMAN is just closing the gate. Sinuhe squeezes through,

dialogues.speaker: SINUHE
dialogues.text: runs through the garden past the lotus pool to house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: rushes through just as another SERVANT is closing the doors.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: looks wildly about, presently sees -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: within which lights are being extinguished.  168 169 170 171

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: runs into adjoining room.

dialogues.speaker: SERVANT
dialogues.text: The SERVANT is extinguishing the lights, possibly has all except one extinguished, She looks with surprise to Sinuhe as Sinuhe stops and looks about.

dialogues.speaker: SERVANT
dialogues.text: {with a smile therefore with impertinence) Late is the night, young master,

dialogues.speaker: NEFER'S VOICE
dialogues.text: (from adjoining room) Who is it?

dialogues.speaker: SINUHE
dialogues.text: Sinuhel

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She is being prepared for bed by her slave maid.

dialogues.speaker: NEFER
dialogues.text: Why do you come at this hour? You have left me alone this long day and now I am tired.

dialogues.speaker: SERVANT
dialogues.text: Sinuhe looks to the door through which he has entered, thinking of the merchant he saw leaving Nefer's gate. His expression is touched with cynicism for a moment. In scene behind him, the woman servant titters, holding her hand over her mouth, Sinuhe looks back toward the doorway to Nefer's bedroom, After a pause =

dialogues.speaker: SINUHE
dialogues.text: I have brought the deed. He watches her door. After a moment the curtains part and Nefer appears in doorway. She is smiling.

dialogues.speaker: NEFER
dialogues.text: Will you not come in and say goodnight to me? She turns and disappears into her bedroom. Sinuhe goes toward her doorway. WNefer's maid appears in doorway carrying Nefer's ebony box. She opens the lid and in passing Sinuhe drops the deed into the box,  172 173 55.

dialogues.speaker: AND SINUHE
dialogues.text: She is laying herself down on her couch. Sinuhe appears dn doorway and comes to her. The room is almost in dark- ness. He looks down at her, a victim of regret and of desire.

dialogues.speaker: SINUHE
dialogues.text: Now you possess all that I once owned - my house, my slave, my instruments of a physician - even the clothes I WeAT. She reaches her arms up to him. He takes her hands, kmeels beside the bed. With one hand she brings his head to rest against her breaste

dialogues.speaker: SHOT OF NEFER'S BED
dialogues.text: Into scene drops Nefer's arm and her fingers stroke the cat. After a moment -

dialogues.speaker: SINUHE'S VOICE
dialogues.text: In my dreams I say your name = over and over = Nefernefernefer.

dialogues.speaker: NEFER'S VOICE
dialogues.text: Sinuhe ... why have you chosen to conceal from me that your father owns a house near the docks «.- 7

dialogues.speaker: SINUHE'S VOICE
dialogues.text: (harshly) I cannot give you what is not mine} Nefer's hand is seen to stiffen, then slowly relax and stroke the cat again.

dialogues.speaker: NEFER'S VOICE
dialogues.text: (softly) It is your inheritance, as well you imow. =<- Goodnight, Sinuhe.

dialogues.speaker: AND SOLDIERS
dialogues.text: As mach of the courtyard as we see is filled with soldier They are engaged in a violent, lusty game exercise ~ usin spears as staves they duel, beating each other, yelling with delight,

dialogues.speaker: HOREMHEB
dialogues.text: participates - stripped to the waist, enjoying himself hugely as he almost kills a hapless opponent.

dialogues.speaker: GATE OF BARRACKS TO HOREMHEB
dialogues.text: enters, He is tired. He has come expecting a disagree- able interview. He stops by Horemheb who doesn't see him until -

dialogues.speaker: SINUHE
dialogues.text: You sent for me? Horemheb stops and looks at him. He is breathing hard from his violent exercise. He looks with anger at Sinuhe.

dialogues.speaker: HOREMHEB
dialogues.text: I ought to drive this spear through your head! Are you mad?

dialogues.speaker: SINUHE
dialogues.text: (after pause) Yes.

dialogues.speaker: HOREMHEB
dialogues.text: Pharaoh's daughter is i111! Every hour Akhnaton asks for you.

dialogues.speaker: SINUHE
dialogues.text: {after a pause, beaten) I no longer practice medicine, As Horemheb reacts with great shock and astonishment, Sinuhe turns away and walks back toward the gate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: comes alone down street - slowly, dejectedly. It is very late; the street is deserted. He stops at his modest gateway beside which hangs a signboard on which is painte the symbol of a physician - (use Babylonian symbol akin to modern caduceus). Sinuhe looks at it a moment, takes it down, carries it with him as he goes through gate, across small, dark courtyard into his small house.  178 179 180 181 182 She 57-

dialogues.speaker: INT, ROOM IN SINUHE'S HOUSE
dialogues.text: This is a single room which serves as living quarters, kitchen and doctor's surgery; equipped with a narrow sleeping cot, a hearth, and a corner where there are stools, a low table, and where Sinuhe's physician tools and medicines are kept. It is very dark in here, only a feeble glow from night sky filters in through some windows high in the wall. Sinuhe makes his way to a lamp. He does not see that Merit is seated on his sleep- ing cot, where she has been waiting for his arrival.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Her eyes follow him. Probably she is frightened inside herself, but her expression shows also a determined resolution.

dialogues.speaker: SINUHE
dialogues.text: Even when he gets the lamp lighted he doesn't immediately see her. He looks again at the sign he has brought in- side with him, his face bleak for a moment before he tosses the sign aside. His eyes are caught by some sur- gical instruments, of stone and copper, lying on the table. He reaches for a bag and begins to pack them away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sight is too much for Merit.

dialogues.speaker: MERIT
dialogues.text: (distressed) Sinuhe! TwO SHOT - NIGHT Startled, he drops the instruments, whirls around. For & long moment they look at each other across the room before -

dialogues.speaker: MERIT
dialogues.text: (frankly, determined) I have been waiting --

dialogues.speaker: SINUHE
dialogues.text: (interrupting, harshly) If it is a doctor's advice you seek, see him who will occupy this house tomorrow! She shakes her head violently to stop him. Understanding that this is not the purpose of her visit, he studies her. He walks across the room slowly to her. She meets his look for a long time before - (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 182 (Cont.)

dialogues.speaker: MERIT
dialogues.text: You were a fine doctor. Your life was rising like the sun. Will you let this woman -- ?

dialogues.speaker: SINUHE
dialogues.text: {again interrupt- ing, harshly) Did Kaptah send you?! Of course he is driving against her out of contempt for himself, out of guilt, out of a despair which he will not acknowledge.

dialogues.speaker: MERIT
dialogues.text: (quietly, control- ling herself) I need no one to tell me what to do. His look acknowledges that he kmows how true this is. He refuses to acknowledge anything more and -

dialogues.speaker: SINUHE
dialogues.text: (harshly) Then why did you come? Her eyes drop away. Her breathing comes more rapidly. As her fright increases, but as her determination in- creases also -

dialogues.speaker: MERIT
dialogues.text: (quietly) For many nights you have been absent from the Inn. For many nights - alone on my sleeping mat - I have thought of you.

dialogues.speaker: SINUHE
dialogues.text: (deliberately per- verse, sarcastic) What are you trying to say, sweet Merit? (of course he knows)

dialogues.speaker: MERIT
dialogues.text: (with an uncontrol- lable outburst) What it should not be necessary for me to say when you come home at this hour and find me waiting for youl! She has said it - it is out. She looks at him openly. She is still frightened at what she has decided, but (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sh2 59. 182 (Cont.1) 183 it has been decided. For ea long moment he looks at her. Deep in his heart he has feelings which he will not acknowledge.

dialogues.speaker: SINUHE
dialogues.text: (in the anger of despair) You are a little late! If you would take her place, change your eyes from brown to green ~- change your name to that one which means beautiful so that I shall repeat it over and over! Sprinkle your hair with gold, paint your mouth red ~~ change your heart to evil -- | (stops himself) Seeing that her eyes flood with tears, he drives with harsher cruelty.

dialogues.speaker: SINUHE
dialogues.text: You wish to help me? Then do! (produces a scroll) With this I deed her my inheritance --

dialogues.speaker: MERIT
dialogues.text: (rises with horror) No, Sinuhe!

dialogues.speaker: SINUHE
dialogues.text: The home in which my aged parents live - the tomb they have prepared for their eternal rest -~ {

dialogues.speaker: MERIT
dialogues.text: You cannot do this!

dialogues.speaker: SINUHE
dialogues.text: It needs the signature of witnesses -- be the first to sign! He holds it out to her. She strikes it from his hand.

dialogues.speaker: MERIT
dialogues.text: The gods take pity! Breaking into sobs she runs out. Sinuhe looks after her. Then slowly, without spirit, he stoops to pick up the document.

dialogues.speaker: DAY
dialogues.text: Gate is being opened and Sinuhe is being let in. He walks as if half drugged, as if he has slept too long under the narcotic of shame. From ahead of him he hears the sound of some soft music, stops momentarily to look at ~  60.

dialogues.speaker: SLAVE ORCHESTRA
dialogues.text: Lying on a couch of mats Nefer is idly picking at some e fruits and dates, while three of four members of her GIRL-SLAVE ORCHESTRA entertain her. Today her hair is dyed red = her jewelry is green to match her eyes, except for a magnificent diamond she wears in her headpiece - which stone we have seen previously in the headpiece of the Babylonian Merchant when he came out of her gate. She sees Sinuhe, watches him a moment then -

dialogues.speaker: NEFER
dialogues.text: (pleasantly complaining) How late you are.

dialogues.speaker: DAY
dialogues.text: bringing Sinuhe to her, slowly, eyes on ground.

dialogues.speaker: SINUHE
dialogues.text: (lifelessly) I have deeded to you the home of my parents.

dialogues.speaker: NEFER
dialogues.text: (as before) I had begun to think that I had grown old and ugly in your eyes. e He fumbles in his belt, takes out the document, holds i She smiles, but makes no move to take it.

dialogues.speaker: NEFER
dialogues.text: Today you shail know my heart's gratitude. He hesitates, hands her document. In the last second he almost withholds it as he sees the diamond. Not kmowing the reason for his hesitation, Nefer, after she has the document -

dialogues.speaker: NEFER
dialogues.text: (lightly) Or tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: SINUHE
dialogues.text: (with a quietness which she doesn't yet realize as deadly) That diamond is new? She hesitates a moment, waiting to see if there is any- thing more to it than a simple question; when he says e nothing more - (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: NEFER
dialogues.text: (lightly) It was once a queen's I am told. She turns away, finding her ebony box, on tiles beside her couch, opens lid of box.

dialogues.speaker: SINUHE
dialogues.text: (as before) I have seen it before. She stops all movement, alerted, but not looking at him.

dialogues.speaker: SINUHE
dialogues.text: On the headdress of a Babylonian merchant.

dialogues.speaker: NEFER
dialogues.text: She throws a look at him, hesitates, makes the cynical decision that he from whom she has taken everything so easily, is easily handled = turns away again, her look completely away from him, deposits the deed in her ebony box during -

dialogues.speaker: NEFER
dialogues.text: Do not be vexed, Sinuhe. I deceived him. He was a paunchy man, as fat as a pig -~ (earning back, stops abruptly, fright widening her eyes) Sinuhe. (a second later, in terror) Sinuhe!!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With a sound that is half groan, half yell, he grabs her throat with his two hands, gives a jerk and with one heave throws her into the pool in b.g.

dialogues.speaker: ORCHESTRA
dialogues.text: as girls scream, drop their instruments with a jangle, run, scattering, screaming.

dialogues.speaker: IN POOL
dialogues.text: He actually means to drown her - is holding her head under as she struggles. The dye from her hair is stain- ing the water blood red.  she 190 191 192 193 194 195 196 62.

dialogues.speaker: HOUSE
dialogues.text: rush out into garden - mostly women, screaming - but also Nefer's two giant Negroes, who rush forward toward pool.

dialogues.speaker: IN POOL
dialogues.text: He is holding her under -- we are close on them -- we ean see the bubbles of her expiring breath rising out of the red water, Sinuhe's contorted face. As a Negro hurls himself into the pool on top of Sinuhe it is mostly an impression of something coming past camera to make a great splash on the water.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Negro who has come in after Sinuhe heaves him to pool's edge, where he is seized by second Negro, pulled up like a toy, smashed in the face into the trunk of a tree, at the foot of which Sinuhe falls down, half in- sensible. Second Negro out of pool, a rushing blot past camera.

dialogues.speaker: SINUHE, TWO NEGROES
dialogues.text: One Negro picks up Sinuhe, hits him, sending him spinning against Second Negro, who picks him up in his two hands, high into the air over his head, hurls him toward garden gate onto ground, First Negro instantly on him, picks him up, high over head, hurls him toward gate. These giants handle him like a sack of grain.

dialogues.speaker: IN POOL
dialogues.text: as she is being helped out, as she recovers some breath.

dialogues.speaker: TWO NEGROES, SINUHE
dialogues.text: Gate is opened; Sinuhe, with a great heave, is thrown into foreground, into the street; gate is slammed shut.

dialogues.speaker: SINUHE
dialogues.text: On the ground - dirty, bloody, unconscious ~ Sinuhe makes an effort to rise - only a slight, convulsive movement - stiffens into the dirt, After a moment camera pans away slightly. Peering cautiously around the corner of a wall comes the one eye of Keptah.

dialogues.speaker: NIGHT
dialogues.text: It is a simple room ~- (see illustration NAT'L GEOGRAPHIC Oct. 1941, p. 486) + a domestic scene which could happen 4n any home. The child is sick = youngest of Pharaoh's daughters. The mother sits on the bed, cradling the child in her arms. The father paces nervously. The DOCTOR is an old man, who sits on a chair beside the bed. Ona table in front of him is his medical chest. For a moment he consults a papyrus seroll, looks toward the child, obviously unsure of himself,

dialogues.speaker: AKHNATON
dialogues.text: (impatiently) Make haste! The old man looks piteously at Pharaoh. DOCTOR “ Punish me!

dialogues.speaker: PHARAOH
dialogues.text: (brushing this aside) Tell me what's wrong with my child!

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR
dialogues.text: My eyes are old -- I am of the old school, Akhnaton makes an impatient gesture.

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR
dialogues.text: Not many days ago I was present at @ demonstration in the courtyard of @ young physician called Sinuhe, He Who Is Alone -

dialogues.speaker: AKHANATON
dialogues.text: (interrupting - with anguish - as if to himself) Where is Sinuhe!

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR
dialogues.text: I believe that this child suffers from a growth beneath the skull such as he described and that only this young man can save her. At the sound of footsteps approaching, Akhnaton whirls toward doorway.  she 198 64.

dialogues.speaker: HOREMHEB
dialogues.text: As Horemheb appears in doorway, makes obeisance, Akhnaton impatiently gestures him to come in.

dialogues.speaker: AKHNATON
dialogues.text: You have come alone?

dialogues.speaker: HOREMHEB
dialogues.text: (sadly) With bad news. (comes to Akhnaton) His house has been sold --

dialogues.speaker: AKENATON
dialogues.text: (impatiently) I know, I know,

dialogues.speaker: HOREMHEB
dialogues.text: I went this afternoon to the home of his parents. I found that his parents are dead.

dialogues.speaker: AKHNATON
dialogues.text: (even in this moment sympathetic) Oh. ee?

dialogues.speaker: HOREMHEB
dialogues.text: He was not there -- Only a crowd of grieving neighbors and some officers of the law, who were trying to take possession, for this house, too, has been sold. Behind him in doorway Baketamon appears. Horemheb does not at first see her as she enters and walks toward bed.

dialogues.speaker: HOREMHEB
dialogues.text: From there I went to the residence of a certain woman - (voice alters as he catches sight of Baketamon) - with whom he is enamored -- He is searching Baketamon's face, hoping for some sign of recognition from her. But she gives him none, only sitting on the bed beside the Queen to comfort her.

dialogues.speaker: HOREMEEB
dialogues.text: - but this woman denied any imowledge of his whereabouts...

dialogues.speaker: KAPTAH
dialogues.text: This is the principal, all-purpose room of a middle-class home. Sinuhe stands looking about him, horror-stricken. His face and body show the effects of the beating he was given by Nefer's Negroes. Kaptah is beside him, almost weeping. On the bed lie the two shroud-wrapped bodies of Sinuhe's parents. The smoke from the fireplace, by which they have ended their lives, still clouds the ceiling and drifts out through door and high windows into the courtyard.

dialogues.speaker: SINUHE
dialogues.text: (dead tone) How did my parents die?

dialogues.speaker: KAPTAH
dialogues.text: (emotionally) By their own hands, my lord, Smothered with smoke from the hearth. Sinuhe looks about, suffering, looks toward ceiling at --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: which is suspended from the ceiling. It is made with reeds, tied with fowler's knots, daubed with pitch - and begrimed with many years of smoke from the hearth.

dialogues.speaker: SINUHE
dialogues.text: There is the boat in which I drifted down the Nile. (bitterly) In their simplicity they said I was a gift from the gods -- not knowing what evil the gift would bring them.

dialogues.speaker: KAPTAH
dialogues.text: (after pause) Your father left you a letter which he dictated to a scribe.

dialogues.speaker: SINUHE
dialogues.text: Read it.

dialogues.speaker: KAPTAH
dialogues.text: Master, you Imow I cannot read. Sinuhe takes the papyrus roll which Kaptah hands him, unrolls it, and begins to read. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: SINUHE
dialogues.text: I, Semmut, and his wife Kipa send greet~ ings to our son Sinuhe. Throughout your life you have brought us only joy, and great has been our pride in you. We are grieved for your sake because you have met with reverses, and we believe that in all you did you could not help your- self. Do not grieve that you were required to sell our tomb, for all exist- ence is vanity -- we are old, and death comes to us as welcome as sleep to the weary.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as he continues reading only with greatest difficulty. SINUHE © (reading with emotion) Remember always that we blessed you before we left. May all the gods of Egypt protect you from danger, may your heart be shielded from sorrow --- such is the desire of your father and your mother.

dialogues.speaker: NIGHT
dialogues.text: Introduce scene by camera coming through vapor from great vats of copper and/or stone, Horror should not at any time be emphasized nor revolting details shown in this place where the bodies of the dead are mummified. How- ever, well in beg. of scene, almost completely shrouded in vapor, there might be indications of the mechanics by which bodies are carried up to vats on ramps, divested of their shrouds and thrown into the liquid chemicals. But predominantly the effect should be only mystic and weird, a kind of inferno - hell on earth. Possibly a green light cast over scene would be effective. Just before scene is disclosed, we hear -

dialogues.speaker: SINUHE
dialogues.text: I am Sinuhe - called He Who Is Alone - As scene is disclosed - = and my name is written in the Book of Life of the Physicians. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 203 (Cont.)

We see that Sinuhe has already laid down the shroud-wrapp body of his father and is just laying down that of his mother. A group of curious workers gather around. These are of the lowest order of human beings, ragged, unkempt, filthy. A big fellow, whose only slightly bet- ter appearance identifies him as the FOREMAN, approaches Sinuhe as the latter straightens.

dialogues.speaker: SINUHE
dialogues.text: Into this House of Death I have brought the bodies of a man and a woman to be preserved by your art that they may enjoy eternal life in the hereafter.

dialogues.speaker: A WORKER
dialogues.text: (with evil eagerness) Is the woman young? (stoops to lift shroud)

dialogues.speaker: 2ND WORKER
dialogues.text: (angrily leaping to intercept him) By lot this one belongs to me! The first worker had peeped beneath the shroud, reacts with distaste.

dialogues.speaker: 1ST WORKER
dialogues.text: Take her! She's an old hag! With one blow, Sinuhe knocks them both aside. The Foreman seizes hold of Sinuhe to prevent further violence

dialogues.speaker: SINUHE AND FOREMAN
dialogues.text: as Sinuhe subsides.

dialogues.speaker: FOREMAN
dialogues.text: (wheedling - avaricious.) Are you a noble lord? Have you gold?

dialogues.speaker: SINUEE
dialogues.text: The pennies to pay for having my parents transported here were loaned me by my former slave. {as Foreman reacts) In truth I have nothing --

dialogues.speaker: FOREMAN
dialogues.text: (off to workers; carelessly) Throw these bodtes in the river. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: SINUHE
dialogues.text: (seizing him desperately) I will work for you to pay! The Foreman looks at him as if he can't credit his ears.

dialogues.speaker: GROUP OF WORKERS
dialogues.text: who also in their animal way look at Simhe as if he is crazy - demented.

dialogues.speaker: SINUHE'S VOICE
dialogues.text: Iwill serve you in this House of Death for as long as is needed]!

dialogues.speaker: FOREMAN
dialogues.text: Only the accursed of the gods or eriminals take service here.

dialogues.speaker: SINUEE
dialogues.text: There is no man here who is not better than I! As camera goes away through vapor again:

dialogues.speaker: RIVER NILE
dialogues.text: It is a winding narrow valley in the desert with red and purple cliffs and hills. Bathed in moonlight, it is a beautiful and peaceful sight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Built into the face of a hill is the white portico and entrance to a royal tomb. (See illustration NAT'L GEO- GRAPHIC Oct. 1941 p.503.) The GRAVE ROBBER is a former criminal, as his mtilated ears testify. But he has a good heart. The three men are smoothing flat the sand over the graves which they have dug for Simbhe's parents rather near the doorway to the tomb.

dialogues.speaker: GRAVE ROBBER
dialogues.text: Do you not know that it is forbidden for any but peeple of royal blood to be buried in the Valley of the Kings? (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: KAPTAH
dialogues.text: (in bad humor) Every child knows this!

dialogues.speaker: GRAVE ROBBER
dialogues.text: I marvel that you dare to lay the spirits of your parents of common pirth near this tomb of a sacred Queen.

dialogues.speaker: SINUHE
dialogues.text: (quietly) My parents hed very little in their earthly life. (after a pause) You can go now, Kaptah. I can give you nothing but my gratitude. (turns to grave robber) And you -- you're a kind man though a@ grave robber. (a rueful half laugh) Tomorrow I may join you in your trade -- (to Kapteh) Some day I may see you.

dialogues.speaker: KAPTAH
dialogues.text: The future is hidden, Master. As the two of them start to leave Sinuhe -

dialogues.speaker: THE GRAVE
dialogues.text: 4s seated mourning alone for his parents. After a moment or two he hears a sound down the valley, looks around.

dialogues.speaker: SINUHE AND MERIT
dialogues.text: Merit is walking up the valley, walking past ea half- completed tomb on which work has been abandoned for the night, toward Sinuhe. Sinuhe peers, not yet able to identify who is coming.

dialogues.speaker: MOVING SHOT
dialogues.text: bringing her toward Simhe. She carries a woven basket . of provisions and @ rolled-up mat of the type used for sleeping.

dialogues.speaker: SINUHE
dialogues.text: He sees that it is Merit, jumps to his feet. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: SINUHE
dialogues.text: Stay away! For forty days and nights I have labored in the House of Death.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Merit comes along. She is completely self=-possessed, sure of herself - but is nowise offensively so - only with the beautiful simplicity which in every way implies that yesterday is dead yesterday and tonight is new.

dialogues.speaker: MERIT
dialogues.text: (quietly) Kaptah told me I would find you here.

dialogues.speaker: SINUHE
dialogues.text: The odor of death is on me. She steps near him, at what might be termed a respectful distance, fearing that to come further without his con- sent might offend him.

dialogues.speaker: MERIT
dialogues.text: I have brought wine and honey cakes.

dialogues.speaker: _ SINUHE
dialogues.text: I have joined a cast which is shunned by every living being! Merit finds a spot close by where the sand is smooth, sets down her burdens, seats herself and opens her bas- ket. He watches her, dumbfounded.

dialogues.speaker: MERIT
dialogues.text: She looks up at him. With simplicity, with the slight- est kind of gesture, indicates an invitation to come sit beside her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: bringing Sinuhe to her. He looks down at her for a long time, understanding why she has come but not quite yet believing. Merit smiles.

dialogues.speaker: MERIT
dialogues.text: It's very simple, Simbhe -- almost too simple to need words - what I give, I give only from the heart. He stoops swiftly and gathers her into his arms. Camera pans away and up, during which movement -

dialogues.speaker: NIGHT TO DAY
dialogues.text: At first we see only the clear night sky, stars, one star brighter than all the rest. Then the sky brightens into dawn and the stars pale out as predawn light glows. An eagle is heard to scream in the sky.

dialogues.speaker: PARENTS
dialogues.text: awakens with a start. His arms are in a position as if he had held someone in them. By first impulse he looks beside him ~-- Merit is gone -- there is only the print o her sleeping mat in the sand, Then he hears a noise in the valley below him -- looks.

dialogues.speaker: FROM SINUHE'S PERSPECTIVE
dialogues.text: Someone is driving a chariot rapidly up the valley.

dialogues.speaker: CHARIOT
dialogues.text: He is driving his team at furious pace.

dialogues.speaker: NEAR TOMB OF SINUHE'S PARENTS
dialogues.text: Sinuhe recognizes Horemheb - rises.

dialogues.speaker: HOREMHEB
dialogues.text: Horses rearing and pawing the air as Horemheb pulls them to an abrupt stop - dust rising in clouds as Horemheb jumps out.

dialogues.speaker: HOREMHEB AND SINUHE
dialogues.text: There is an air of calmness about Sinuhe of accepting fat whatever 1t may be, which contrasts with Horemheb's violence, a kind of friendly anger.

dialogues.speaker: HOREMHEB
dialogues.text: The daughter of Pharaoh is dead - for lack of the medical help which you could have provided! You are being searched for everywhere!

dialogues.speaker: SINUHE
dialogues.text: (calmly, resigned) Since you have found me and you are the captain of Pharaoh's palace guard -~

dialogues.speaker: HOREMHEB
dialogues.text: (violently) Is this the way you think I interpret friendship? Get int (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 42 72. 222 (Cont.) 223 22h 225 226 227 228 He grabs hold of Sinuhe's clothing at the shoulder, practically throws him into the chariot, jumps in after him, applies whip to team.

dialogues.speaker: CHARIOT
dialogues.text: as chariot 1s driven away in the direction from which it came, at the rapid speed with which it came.

dialogues.speaker: CHARIOT
dialogues.text: Chariot comes around corner at a furious pace, almost directly at camera. Horses paw the air as Horemheb pulls them to a stop. He pushes Sinuhe out of chariot, throws something after him. .

dialogues.speaker: HOREMHEB
dialogues.text: (rapidly, incisively) This is as far as I dare take you. Here's a purse - there's silver in it - ali I have!

dialogues.speaker: SINUHE
dialogues.text: Horemhebd --

dialogues.speaker: HOREMHEB
dialogues.text: A ship sails down the river this morning! Take it! Your life is forfeit in Egypt -- never dare to return! . He applies whip to team.

dialogues.speaker: SINUHE
dialogues.text: Stands looking after him, holding the purse, gratitude for Horemheb's friendship, many other things passing through his mind. Turning, he sees -

dialogues.speaker: DAY .
dialogues.text: are approaching.

dialogues.speaker: SINUHE
dialogues.text: looks around, wondering where to hide. Over his shoulder he sees: EXT. “STREET TO THE DOCKS" FROM SINUHE'S PERSPECTIVE - DA The entrance'to the Inn, "The Crocodile's Tail."  she 229 230 231 232 233 23h 73.

dialogues.speaker: NEAR GATEWAY TO THE INN
dialogues.text: runs toward the Inn. As he arrives at the gateway to the Inn he sees another squadron of soldiers beginning to com out of the Inn. He runs past, gets past just in time, ducks into another doorway. Camera movement makes a close shot of him there. He watches the soldiers, looks around, wondering where he will be safe. Presently he hears ~

dialogues.speaker: KAPTAH'S VOICE
dialogues.text: (from 0.8., distant calling, syllables drawn out) He Who Is Alone! Sinuhe looks in that direction.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: rather far away, hiding in a doorway, is frantically signaling to Sinuhe. Well beyond Kaptah at the end of the street we see the suggestion of a river ship, its sails being hoisted.

dialogues.speaker: DAY
dialogues.text: Sinuhe comes out of his hiding place, goes down the stree in direction of Kaptah and the ship. First he walks, then he runs.

dialogues.speaker: SOLDIERS
dialogues.text: Soldiers are posted at the gateway as if they intend to remain there. Merit comes out of the gateway. She looks nervously at the soldiers. She looks up and down the street.

dialogues.speaker: MERIT
dialogues.text: Of course she has not seen Sinuhe - but it is as if some intuition has told her that he has been near. She is afraid.

dialogues.speaker: DAY
dialogues.text: over which we hear:

dialogues.speaker: OLD SINUHE'S VOICE
dialogues.text: And so I shook the black mud of Egypt off my feet.

dialogues.speaker: EXT, THE HOUSE ON DESERT
dialogues.text: For a moment he muses rather sadly.

dialogues.speaker: OLD SINUHE
dialogues.text: As many as the sands of this desert were the follies of my youth. Heavy was my punishment -- then, as now, I was an exile from my home. He raises his head, His tone changes as he begins another story.

dialogues.speaker: OLD SINUHE
dialogues.text: I saw the whole world. I saw the rulers and the people. I saw the gods the people worshipped.

dialogues.speaker: DAY
dialogues.text: which include: Jehu of the Khabiri (Hebrews); the bull- headed Minotauros of the Cretans and others; many-breaste Astarte; fire-belching Baal.

dialogues.speaker: SINUHE AND KAPTAH
dialogues.text: Camera slowly crosses narrow street. We get enough of the color to realize that we are in a land foreign from Egypt There are Syrians, Hittites, Mitannians, Hebrews. There is the suggestion of a camel caravan.

dialogues.speaker: OLD SINUHE'S VOICE
dialogues.text: Life gave me no delight -- my heart cried for my home. He who has once drunk of Nile water will forever yearn to be by the Nile again -- his thirst cannot be quenched by the waters of any other land! Camera arrives at Sinuhe and Kaptah. They are the only ones who wear Egyptian clothes. A definite suggestion of weariness in Sinuhe suggests that a considerable time has elapsed since he left Egypt - as much as a couple of year His clothing and Kaptah's are rather seedy. As Kapteah watches him with his gimlet single eye, Sinuhe is looking around him in a manner which plainly says that he is an alien in a strange land. Seeing Kaptah's eye on him, he returns the slave's look for a long moment before - (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: SINUHE
dialogues.text: Kaptah, is there no means by which we can ever return to Egypt?

dialogues.speaker: KAPTAR
dialogues.text: Only one, master. By means of the only thing in which every man believes - whatever his color. (after a pause) Gold.

dialogues.speaker: SINUHE
dialogues.text: (entertaining the idea, half question, half statement ) Gold.

dialogues.speaker: KAPTAR
dialogues.text: Which can buy anything.

dialogues.speaker: SINUHE
dialogues.text: (with a smile, but not at all dismissing the idea) You are a cynic, slave.

dialogues.speaker: KAPTAH
dialogues.text: (half mischievous, half serious) You are a cynic also, master ~ without yet knowing it.

dialogues.speaker: MONEY
dialogues.text: of many lands and sorts - rings of metal, jewels, crude coins, clay tablets on which sums are written in Assyrian cuneiforms. .

dialogues.speaker: A SICK BOY
dialogues.text: It is a wild and barbaric setting lit with flickering torchlight. KING AZIRU is a giant savage king with a curled, blue-black beard. He is sitting on a camp stool by a bed on which his SON of about twelve years of age li tossing feverishly. Aziru's CHIEFTAINS are almost as bdar baric looking as he. With Kaptah standing by, Sinuhe rise beside him after having examined the sick boy. Aziru follows Sinuhe with his eyes and we see that tears are running like rivulets from his eyes into his beard. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: AZIRU
dialogues.text: Save my son, gifted Egyptian, and I will give you one-tenth of all my wealth, as I am Kingt

dialogues.speaker: SINUHE
dialogues.text: (gravely) Your son's spirit is drifting close to the shores of the Western Land from which none has returned. (whispers to Kaptah) A simple infection. (to Aziru) Two-tenths of your wealth, King.

dialogues.speaker: KING, DOCTORS
dialogues.text: Get the suggestion of bigness out of impression and detai ~ Babylonian drawings, highly colored, on a wall - impres sive throne. KING BURNABURIASH of Babylon sits on the throne -- a nasty, beardless boy. One of his jaws is swollen out to the size of an orange. Two of his DOCTORS stand by dressed in the weirdly feather-like garment of their calling. There may be a suggestion of others. On their faces on the floor in front of the throne are Sinuh and Kaptah, Their clothing is now rich and they are both loaded down with ornaments of gold and precious stones.

dialogues.speaker: KING BURNABURIASH
dialogues.text: (in a petulant tone) Egyptian, your fame has traveled ahead of you, but from where I sit I can see nothing remarkable about you.

dialogues.speaker: KAPTAE
dialogues.text: My master can cure the blind, bring the dead to life -- !

dialogues.speaker: KING BURNABURIASH
dialogues.text: Silence! Another word and a live slave will be dead. (looks at Sinuhe, waits)

dialogues.speaker: SINUHE
dialogues.text: I perceive that your Majesty is possessed of the nastiest devils I have ever encoun- tered. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: a2 TT. 240 (Cont.) After the King of Babylon looks with fear at his doctors

dialogues.speaker: SINUHE
dialogues.text: (whispers with amuse- ment to Kaptah) A toothache. Sinuhe gets to his feet, looks at the King boldly. Kaptah starts to get to his feet, thinks better of it and goes down again.

dialogues.speaker: BURNABURIASH
dialogues.text: (craftily) What price do you beg for to cast out these devils?

dialogues.speaker: SINUBE
dialogues.text: My fee - like my skill - will amaze you.

dialogues.speaker: DAY
dialogues.text: which is a fearful beast made with two heads - man and animal - the body of a lion, wings, a serpent for tail.

dialogues.speaker: OLD SINUHE'S VOICE
dialogues.text: I came to the land of the Hittites.

dialogues.speaker: HITTITE COMMANDER
dialogues.text: This tent is a military tent, severe. Its walls are hung with military maps. The tent is of medium size and is connected to an adjoining tent by means of a tented pas- sageway. Although we do not see the inside of this se- cond tent, the sounds of ringing metal which come from it suggest that it is a big field armorers' shop. Sit- ting on a camp chair is PRINCE SHUBBILULIUMA. He is a man of middle age who, though he wears a military uniform suggests a diplomat more than a commander. The group of his COMMANDERS who are around him, however, look like just what they are - and transplanted to the modern world would be Nazis or Soviets... The Prince is wearing a ban- dage slant-wise across an injured eye. Sinuhe is care- fully examining this eye, using a glass which magnifies. Kaptah is standing nearby looking around, his interest on the maps. There is silence until Sinuhe completes his examination. As he straightens up - PRINCE SHUBB. Can you make my eye whole again?

dialogues.speaker: SINUHE
dialogues.text: Between a serious question and an answer there should be an interval of thought. He has perceived the direction of Kaptah's look, He, too, looks at the military maps on the wall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It shows the land of the Hittites, Syria and Egypt. Two colored lines plainly indicate military routes, one lead- ing across the sea past Crete to the Nile, another land- ward through Syria to the Nile, the lines converging at the delta.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO SCENE
dialogues.text: The commanders are looking uneasily at each other. The Prince seems completely unruffled. (CONPINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 542 195 2h, (Cont.) 2k5 2h6 PRINCE SHUBB. Do you see something in that map more interesting than in my eye?

dialogues.speaker: SINUHE
dialogues.text: At least stranger to me, Prince, for I am not a military man. if my name were Horemheb I think I should con- clude that you Hittites are planning an invasion against the land of Egypt. There is an appreciable start from the commanders at this. The Prince looks around at them unruffled and smiling.

dialogues.speaker: PRINCE SHUBB-
dialogues.text: It matters not what this man sees. In our land he is an honored guest whom we like so much we are going to keep here for life. (to Simuhe) Shall we agree on your fee? (laughs ) Do not demand more than half the Kingdom.

dialogues.speaker: SINUHE
dialogues.text: I shall astonish you. My fee shall be exactly of the size of the foreign particle which has lodged in your princely eye. The Prince laughs and Sirmhe laughs with him. He bends forward to business. He has one of the Commanders hold open the Prince's eye. From a portable medicine kit he takes a small copper instrument like a tweezer, another like a mimute Imife. Kaptah begins to walk around the tent. This makes the commanders nervous, especially when Kaptah gets near the passageway leading to the tent of the armorers.

dialogues.speaker: SINUHE
dialogues.text: takes from the Prince's eye a small sliver of metal which he hides in his clothing. He straightens up. .

dialogues.speaker: SINUHE
dialogues.text: Done.

dialogues.speaker: PRINCE SHUBB.
dialogues.text: (to Sinuhe) Thank you. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ou2

2h6 (Gont.) 2h7 248 PRINCE SHUBB (Cont. ) (to the others) My gratitude shall be expressed as follows: this man and his companion are to be allowed to see what they wish in this land, hear what they wish, travel anywhere ~ except across the border. The commanders smile and laugh with appreciation of the Prince's humor. Sinuhe bows. He walks away, picks up Kaptah and they go together through the passageway lead- ing into the big tent.

dialogues.speaker: DAY
dialogues.text: In this place weapons of all sorts are made - spears, scythes for chariots, knives... It is the close of the day and many of the armorers are leaving their tasks and going out of the tent, but some still hammer at their forges.

dialogues.speaker: ARMORER
dialogues.text: Sinuhe and Kaptah come along looking about at what they can see. Sinuhe seems to be increasingly possessed of an almost unbearably great inner excitement. Presently they come upon the forge of AN ARMORER. Obviously he knows Sinuhe for he smiles and nods a greeting to him.

dialogues.speaker: SINUHE
dialogues.text: My friend, -- (from out of clothing takes particle removed from Prince's eye) ~ from the eye of your Prince I have removed a small sliver of a metal with which you Hittites make your weapons. What is it called?

dialogues.speaker: ARMORER
dialogues.text: I cannot answer.

dialogues.speaker: SINUHE
dialogues.text: I think this new metal will change the history of the world. What is it called?

dialogues.speaker: ARMORER
dialogues.text: I cannot answer. Ee freezes at something offscene.  2k9 250 81.

dialogues.speaker: INCLUDE SEVERAL OF THE COMMANDERS
dialogues.text: who were in the Prince's tent and who are now coming by. Beyond them we see that the last of the armorers are quitting work and that in a moment or two this particular armorer will be the last. The commanders are in very good spirits.

dialogues.speaker: A COMMANDER
dialogues.text: (to armorer) Tell this guest anything he wants to imow. He and his companions laugh at the joke as they pass along to go out of the tent.

dialogues.speaker: SINUHE, KAPTAH, ARMORER
dialogues.text: The armorer goes to a rack on which are kept many weapons of various sorts including some copper and some of the new metal. He picks up a spear with ea copper head. He drives it against his stone anvil. The spearhead bends double,

dialogues.speaker: ARMORER
dialogues.text: (with contempt) Egyptian copper’ He picks up another, drives it against the anvil. It, too, bends double.

dialogues.speaker: ARMORER
dialogues.text: (with contempt) Egyptian bronze! {tosses it aside) He picks up a third, of the new metal. He drives it against the stone anvil. The weapon chips a piece from the stone.

dialogues.speaker: ARMORER
dialogues.text: Iron.

dialogues.speaker: SINUHE
dialogues.text: (repeats ) Iron. (then) Sell me a spearhead of this metal,

dialogues.speaker: ARMORER
dialogues.text: This I cannot dol Simuhe doesn't bargain with him - not with words. He takes a richly jeweled bracelet off his arm, tosses it at the armorer's feet. The armorer's eyes glitter but (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 250 (Cont.) 251 his face sets and he stubbornly shakes his head. One by one Simuhe divests himself of every jewel and ornament he wears, until the armorer ig in a sweat. Kaptah is looking on in horror.

dialogues.speaker: KAPTAH
dialogues.text: (cries out) Master, have you taken leave of your senses] Sinuhe begins on Kaptah, taking off from him every piece of value.

dialogues.speaker: KAPTAH
dialogues.text: (almost in tears) Take my life but not these! When all is on the ground in front of the armorer Sinuhe looks at him. The armorer walks to the rack, takes a spearhead, without handle, brings it surreptitiously and hands it to Simuhe, With a look of joy Sinuhe takes it and hides it in his clothing. As armorer goes to pick up the wealth camera moves to close shot of Sinuhe and Kaptah who, during this latter part of the scene, has been rendered speechless in his anguish.

dialogues.speaker: KAPTAH
dialogues.text: You have given all your wealth for one spearhead of iron?

dialogues.speaker: SINUHE
dialogues.text: (with excitement and oy) With this passport I will dare return to Egypt! Soon we will go -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Begin on close shot. On Old Simuhets face there is exactly the same expression we have seen on Sinuhets face in the land of the Hittites, and in direct contimation of the speech in the preceding scene -

dialogues.speaker: OLD SINUHE
dialogues.text: - home! Camera pulls slowly back.

dialogues.speaker: OLD SINUHE
dialogues.text: We escaped to a ship, on which we took passage as two merchants of Syria. It was prudent that we enter Egypt in (CONTINUED )
255 OLD SINUHE (Cont.) disguise for I was under sentence of death, and my only chance lay in getting to Horemheb with my great secret. He pauses, his tone changes.

dialogues.speaker: OLD SINUHE
dialogues.text: How my heart leaped when from the horizon rose the sight of the delta of the Nile.

dialogues.speaker: OLD SINUHE'S VOICE
dialogues.text: Again I would hear the whispering of the reeds at sunrisel

dialogues.speaker: OLD SINUHE'S VOICE
dialogues.text: See the lotus flowers unfolding on the shore}

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The ship is moving slowly up the Nile. In beg. we see the Sphinx and the three great pyramids past which the ship is moving | ~- but the Sphinx and the pyramids as th were in those days ~- not crumbled away, but white with limestone and deseratea with bright colors. Sinuhe and EKaptah are in scene, looking about and looking ahead, Both are in disguise, shrouded in the long enveloping gowns and headpieces of Syrian merchants.

dialogues.speaker: OID SINUHE'S VOICE
dialogues.text: At last I sailed past the majestic pyramids. Up my green valley watered by the Nile? (a pause, then ominously) But what did I find?

dialogues.speaker: SHOTS
dialogues.text: to show disaster: PARCHED EARTH, veined with DEEP (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: oye 8k. 255 (Cont.) 256 FISSURES - WATER WHEELS and a SHADOFF (water derrick) standing still and useless - CROPS, burning with drought the WATER OF THE NILE, dirty, dead bodies drifting among crocodiles...

dialogues.speaker: OLD SINUHE'S VOICE
dialogues.text: I found Egypt in ruins -- swept by drought, famine, sickness and death!

dialogues.speaker: PASSERS-BY
dialogues.text: Sinuhe and Kaptah are coming along, obviously having just arrived, for Kaptah is burdened with their travel- ing bags. They move cautiously, alert for any signs of danger, and Kaptah is very frightened.

dialogues.speaker: KAPTAH
dialogues.text: Better we had not come here, where if they do not hang us, we'll surely starve!

dialogues.speaker: SINUHE
dialogues.text: We will soon be at the barracks. He reassures himself by feeling the Hittites spearhead which is concealed in his clothing. Propped against a wall is a BEGGAR WOMAN, starving, clothing in rags, with a small CHILD in her lap, tugging at the woman's empty breasts.

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN
dialogues.text: Alms, alms -~- in the name of the gods! Sinuhe stops, stops Kaptah.

dialogues.speaker: SINUHE
dialogues.text: Give this woman alms, Merchant of Syria.

dialogues.speaker: KAPTAH
dialogues.text: (sotto voce, protesting) Our last coppers?

dialogues.speaker: SINUHE
dialogues.text: (to woman) You shall have alms for answers to some questions. The woman holds up her scrawny hands, piteously.

dialogues.speaker: SINUHE
dialogues.text: In Syria we think of Egypt as the most

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 256 (Cont.) 257 258 SINUHE (Cont.) prosperous nation on earth -- yet here we find nothing but misery and famine. From what cause?

dialogues.speaker: BEGGAR WOMAN
dialogues.text: The wicked Pharaoh, cursed be his name!

dialogues.speaker: SINUHE
dialogues.text: (genuinely surprised) You dare speak of your sacred Kirg Akhnaton in this way?

dialogues.speaker: BEGGAR WOMAN
dialogues.text: (venomous ly } He has forbidden to worship with the ancient godsi He has decreed that the people must worship only his god Aton. fhe ancient gods are angry and punish us with drought and famine! Curses rain upon Pharachl! Sinuhe takes the coppers out of Kaptah's reluctant hand and tosses them into the hand of the beggar woman.

dialogues.speaker: BEGGAR, WOMAN
dialogues.text: The ancient gods bless youl Sinuhe and Kaptah move along, the camera moving with them

dialogues.speaker: SINUHE
dialogues.text: Can this be our Egypt - brought to the verge of civil war by a petty squabble over gods? Ahead of them they hear the growing sound of many people and stop, look.

dialogues.speaker: PEOPLE
dialogues.text: The granaries are separated from the street by a high wall and strong gates. Above the wall project the high domes of the structures in which grain is stored. A large and curious mob of people tries to get to the gates to break into the granaries. The gates are being defen- ded by a not large detachment of Egyptian foot soldiers.

dialogues.speaker: THE PEOPLE
dialogues.text: somewhere on their costumes the symbol of the Cross of Life. Others wear symbol of the Horns. They fight against the soldiers with anything they can lay their hands on -- stones and sticks.  5h2 259 260 261 262 86.

dialogues.speaker: THE SOEDIERS
dialogues.text: They are all armed only with spears - spears of wood, and these they do not use as weapons but hold them in a lateral position trying to form a sort of "chain" with which to hold the people back.

dialogues.speaker: ON STREET
dialogues.text: Kapteah, frightened, would turn back, but Sinuhe takes hold of him.

dialogues.speaker: SINUEE
dialogues.text: This is our way to the barracks. , He pulls Kapteah forward.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ~- DaY to develop the course of the fighting. It is obvious that the mob will win for their weight against the wood~ en spears is causing them to break - snap like matches.

dialogues.speaker: FOOT SOLDIERS
dialogues.text: At opening of scene a small detachment of FOOT SOLDIERS is being dispatched on its way, apparently to help quiet the riot before the granary. They pass by in f.g. and when they have gone disclose Sinuhe and Kaptah, who are approaching the gateway of the barracks. Kaptah is staunching the flow of blood from his wounded face. We see in f.g. the Egyptian LIEUTENANT who has dispatched the troops. We have seen this man before, before he was a lieutenant, when he was the sergeant who brought Sinuhe and Horemheb to Akhnaton's throne room. Beside him are a couple of other officers and beyond him, in the court- yard of the barracks, can be seen a few other soldiers.

dialogues.speaker: LIEUTENANT
dialogues.text: (in disgust to the other officers) Of what use to send troops who are forbidden to fight! He goes through gateway into courtyard of barracks. At the same time Sinuhe and Kaptah arrive at gateway and start through. They are held back by a sentry and his spear,

dialogues.speaker: SENTRY
dialogues.text: None enter here.  52 263 26k 265 87.

dialogues.speaker: DAY
dialogues.text: The Lieutenant turns to see what is happening.

dialogues.speaker: LIEUTENANT
dialogues.text: What do you want?

dialogues.speaker: SINUHE
dialogues.text: To see Horemheb. With a gesture the Lieutenant orders the sentry to let Sinuhe and Kaptah enter. They come to the Lieutenant and other officers. Kaptah is holding back, nervous at being so close to the armed authority. His manner is enough to incite suspicion.

dialogues.speaker: LIEUTENANT
dialogues.text: What can a Syrian merchant want with the Commander?

dialogues.speaker: SINUHE
dialogues.text: I have something of great value for him.

dialogues.speaker: LIEUTENANT
dialogues.text: Horemheb is not here. I am in command. Give it to me.

dialogues.speaker: SINUHE
dialogues.text: (stubbornly ) It is for Horemheb alone. The Lieutenant is studying Sinuhse, not only with suspi- cion but with the birth of recognition. He goes closer to him. Sinuhe, sensing danger, averts his face.

dialogues.speaker: LIEUTENANT, SINUHE, KAPTAH IN B.G.
dialogues.text: Kaptah is extremely nervous. The Lieutenant reaches out and grabs hold of Simhe's chin, jerks him around so Sinuhe's face is fully disclosed to him. Sinuhe tries to remain calm.

dialogues.speaker: LIEUTENANT
dialogues.text: Youtre no Syrian - and I'm beginning to remember you. Simuhe makes a break.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sinuhe tries to get to the gate, but the officers who were with the Lieutenant grab hold of him and other sol- diers rush up to help. At the same time, Kaptah makes a break and in the excitement he manages to get away, (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 265 (Cont.) 266 267 268 through the gate to the street, where he disappears from sight.

dialogues.speaker: AT SINUHE
dialogues.text: In the struggle the Hittite spearhead, ‘which Sinuhe car- ries in his clothing, is loosened and falls with a clang to the paving stones.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Sinuhe, restrained by the soldiers, tries to pick up the spearhead, the Lieutenant's foot steps on it.

dialogues.speaker: SOLDIERS
dialogues.text: Lieutenant picks up the spearhead and examines it.

dialogues.speaker: LIEUTENANT
dialogues.text: (as a man whose sus- picions are confirmed) For Horemheb? (holds spearhead like a dagger)

dialogues.speaker: SINUHE
dialogues.text: {hotly protesting) If you recognize me, you know I am his friend! Take me to him!

dialogues.speaker: LIEUTENANT
dialogues.text: (to others) This man is under sentence of death -- put him in chains...

dialogues.speaker: INT, PRISON CELL
dialogues.text: It is almost like night in here, though it is day. A little early morning light comes through a very high, very small window. Sinuhe is in chains, Unable to walk on account of the chains, he sits on the dirty floor, his back propped against a stone wall ~ a victim of apprehension and despair. There is some unspeakably unappetizing food in a bowl on the floor nearby which he has not touched, He is unshaven, his clothing and hair are matted with the dirty straw on which he has slept -- all indications are that he has been in prison for at least forty-eight hours, Presently he hears, as a source of even greater apprehension, the sound of marching feet, obviously military, approaching.

dialogues.speaker: A SQUADRON OF SOLDIERS
dialogues.text: marching past. Through some doorway in b.g., we see an indication of a street and daylight.

dialogues.speaker: INT, SINUHE'S CELL
dialogues.text: He can interpret what he hears in only one way ~- that the hour of his execution is at hand. He looks toward the cell door.

dialogues.speaker: LIEUTENANT
dialogues.text: Soldiers appear first, stop outside the door. Then the Lieutenant, who unlocks the door.

dialogues.speaker: SINUHE
dialogues.text: is now sure that his fears are well grounded. Then abruptly his expression alters tremendously into amaze- ment as he sees:

dialogues.speaker: BAKETAMON
dialogues.text: Dressed in a flowing gown of white linen, immaculate, wearing ornaments of her rank, Baketamon appears like a vision in the cell doorway. Sinuhe tries to move, manages despite his chains to prostrate himself on the eell floor.

dialogues.speaker: SINUHE
dialogues.text: Sister of Pharaoh} For a moment the Princess looks down at Sinuhe's figure, her expression completely enigmatic. Then she turns to the Lieutenant, who is fawning and apologetic. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: BAKETAMON
dialogues.text: (peremptorily) Strike this man's chains, Have him bathed and dressed in the finest linen. Bring him to my chariot that I may take him to the Golden House. She turns and walks out of sight down corridor.

dialogues.speaker: SINUHE
dialogues.text: raises his head to look after her in pure amazement.

dialogues.speaker: SINUHE AND TAIA
dialogues.text: Scene begins on a close shot of Sinuhe in the same attitu as the previous scene, that is prostrate on the floor. He has been bathed and dressed in fine linen. The floor, made of tiles, is decorated with gold and semiprecious stones.

dialogues.speaker: QUEEN TAIA'S VOICE
dialogues.text: Arise, Sinuhe - I have much to say to you. Camera pulls back. This room gives out onto the court- yard of the House of Women in which a pleasant fountain plays in the bright sunlight. In the Queen Mother's room are a great number of birds which twitter in cages. The old Queen is sitting cross-legged on a rich mat. She is a curious mixture of royalty and peasantry. On her peasant's hands she wears rich rings. She is drinking ale. Present in the room are the two RUBIANS who are waiting on her. It is obvious also from the fact that they both have drinking cups near at hand, that they have been drinking with her. They are interesting, if somewhat sinister fellows, of a race which has pointed heads as a result of having them shaped when infants; and who wear ivory pins through their noses. The Queen has set aside some work she has been doing, a mat of reeds she has been weaving. Sinuhe gets to his feet. He is astonished at what is happening to him, and bewildered.

dialogues.speaker: SINUHE
dialogues.text: I am here to serve you, Great Queen Mother. Are you 111?

dialogues.speaker: TAIA
dialogues.text: Egypt is ili. (chuckles) And I am Egypt, Sinuhe, in spite of thet puny son of mine who sits on the throne. Do you believe me? . (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: SINUHE
dialogues.text: (carefully) I will believe what the Great Queen Mother tells me to believe.

dialogues.speaker: TAIA
dialogues.text: You will be wise to do so. (then lightly) Drink ale with me. ° (to Nubian) Serve him, (to 2nd Nubian) Hand me my work. (to Sinuhe) Do you like my Nubians? Murderous fellows - I adore them -- (to both Nubians) Run away - but not too far - I may need you. As the Nubians, having done the Queen's bidding, go out - as Sinuhe wonders what he has gotten into -

dialogues.speaker: TAIA
dialogues.text: Sit with me, Sinuhe, I command you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sinuhe sits down near her thinking that now at last some key to the mystery will be given him. But for a space Taia only weaves on her mat, and then -

dialogues.speaker: TATA
dialogues.text: Dontt you admire the way a Queen can weave a mat of reeds? Sinuhe looks with surprise at the mat, watching the flyin fingers of the Queen. Then something about the mat strike him very forcibly. The Queen looks at him and he at her,

dialogues.speaker: SINUHE
dialogues.text: (carefully) Are those fowler's knots?

dialogues.speaker: TAIA
dialogues.text: (lightly) Was I not born a bird-catcher's daughter? Tell me, Sinuhe, -- you said you were born in the same year as Akhnaton. In exactly what season of that year were you born and abandoned to the Nile in a little boat made of reeds and tied with kmots like these? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 277 (Cont.) 92. For a moment Sinuhe entertains a chilling thought. Then he abandons it as being ridiculous. For some again.

dialogues.speaker: SINUHE
dialogues.text: I am told that Pharach was born in the spring in the sowing season. I came the previous autumn when the floods stood at their highest.

dialogues.speaker: TATA
dialogues.text: I thought I could not have been mistaken.

dialogues.speaker: SINUHE
dialogues.text: (startled) What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: TAIA
dialogues.text: (as 1f changing the sub- ject, but actually not) I will tell you about my own youth. I was only fourteen when I came to this Golden House - to a real Pharaoh. In his House of Women were three hundred wives ~- and I. The others despised me for my dusky skin and broad feet, but I kmew the way to charm Pharaoh -- don't laugh -- I had the beauty of a young body and knew how to use it.

dialogues.speaker: SINUHE
dialogues.text: I am not laughing.

dialogues.speaker: TAIA
dialogues.text: It was my resolve that no other wife should bear a son and bring him alive to Pharaoh until I had done so. reason Sinuhe's look is drawn to her fingers

dialogues.speaker: TATA
dialogues.text: But when I deemed it time for breeding I bore, to my horror, a girl - the proud Baketemon. I have not married her off -- she still remains an arrow in my quiver. Then I bore this son - this puny Akhnaton - but my son whom I placed on the throne -- born in the same year as you - born six months after you --- She stops. There is a breathless tensity between the two.  278 279 280 281 262 93.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: weaving the mat,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Into his mind there comes an image -- which is superim- posed on screen beside his head ~~ of a little reed boat, tied with fowler's knots, swinging from the ceiling of his parents' home. He shakes his head, shakes away the image.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She is smiling at him.

dialogues.speaker: TAIA
dialogues.text: (pleasantly) Egypt is dying, Sinuhe. Egypt is dying because of Akhnaton, Do you not think that it is time that his skull were opened and the physician let his knife slip? The atmosphere between them is extremely tense. Sinuhe sweats. After a long pause he takes a stand,

dialogues.speaker: SINUHE
dialogues.text: As a physician, Great Queen Mother, it is my opinion that you have drunk too much ale.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Sinuhe gets up -

dialogues.speaker: SINUHE
dialogues.text: Is it your divine will that I may leave? For a moment she studies him, her head cocked, her eyes flashing lightning. Then she giggles, as old women do when tipsy. .

dialogues.speaker: TATA
dialogues.text: You amuse me greatly, Sihune - you amuse me greatly. With a wagging motion of her fingers she gives him per- mission to go. He backs away and out the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: stops for a moment to shake away a bad dream, Then he is startled by -

dialogues.speaker: OFFICER'S VOICE
dialogues.text: You - Sinuhe.  283 28). 9h.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Confronting Sinuhe is an EGYPTIAN OFFICER whom he has never seen before, With him a squadron of SOLDIERS. In b.g. is to be seen a chariot, the team of horses held by another SOLDIER.

dialogues.speaker: OFFICER
dialogues.text: You are to come with me.

dialogues.speaker: SINUHE
dialogues.text: (amazed) Where now? But the Officer turns on his heel and walks toward chariot without a further word. As Sinuhe begins to follow and soldiers form to escort him -

dialogues.speaker: COURTIERS AND SOLDIERS
dialogues.text: Our concentration is on a table before the throne on which slaves of the Hittite Prince are heaping presents for Pharaoh. Let us pause to set down some general details which will be picked up as the scene progresses. Some changes have taken place in Akhnaton's court since the last time we saw it. Though the Queen sits on the double throne with him, she doesn't sit with her arm draped about him as before, but aloof and estranged. The children are no longer present, The happy atmosphere is gone. In Akhnaton a marked change is to be noted. He looks posi- tively ill. There are black shadows under his eyes put there by suffering. It is as if the spirit inside him is consuming the body of the man. Decorations of the throne room have been changed -- behind Pharaoh's throne on a wall is to be seen a very large representation of the Cross of Life. It is the single decoration in the room. Now let us return to scene - the table being heaped with rich presents for Pharaoh. And Prince Shubbiluliuma in the capacity of Hittite Ambassador is saying - PRINCE SHUBB. (with oily unctuousness) Accept these few poor gifts, Divine Pharaoh, as evidence of the great love that we Hittites bear for Egypt. Our King, like you, loves only peace -- (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 28 (Cont.) 285 286 Onto the table, into the midst of gifts, is hurled the Hittite spearhead, having been thrown in such a fashion that it strikes the table point-first and actually sings with reverberation. All eyes go to the spearhead. Prince Shubbiluliuma blanches. Horemheb steps into scene.

dialogues.speaker: HOREMHEB
dialogues.text: This Hittite lies! (points to spearhead) There is the evidence of treachery! With a metal called iron the Hittites make weapons with which they plan the conquest of Egypt!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There 1s general consternation, We see that Sinuhe has been brought to the throne room by Horemheb, but has been left in the crowd out of view of the throne.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Hittite Prince, after his start of surprise, con- trives a smile.

dialogues.speaker: AKHNATON
dialogues.text: (with patient chiding) Horemheb, Horemheb - when will you learn? Suspicion breeds only sus- picion, and hatred, hatred, (patientiy, firmly, turning to Eie) Teach this man, High Priest, that blood breeds only blood until we would drown in it.

dialogues.speaker: EIE
dialogues.text: (after hesitant pause) At the Royal Granaries your troops were stoned by your people. I must counsel Pharaoh to make concessions to the Priests of the old gods before this kingdom is lost. For a moment Pharaoh stares at Eie in surprise. Then -

dialogues.speaker: AKHNATON
dialogues.text: (stubbornly) I forgive the people for they know not what they do. Horemheb can stand no more, turns on his heel and appar- ently walks away.  287 288 289 96.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But Horemheb does not mean to leave the room. He parts erowd, seizes hold of Sinuhe and drags him to the throne,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sinuhe throws himself on the floor befpre the throne. Akhnaton leans forward, staring when he sees who it is.

dialogues.speaker: SINURE
dialogues.text: My crime was great and great must be my punishment,

dialogues.speaker: AKENATON
dialogues.text: {after a pause) All of you go. Leave me alone with this man. His tone is enigmatic - it is impossible to tell whether or not it contains a threat to Sinuhe.

dialogues.speaker: THRONE ROOM
dialogues.text: As the last of the people leave, Akhnaton and Sinuhe are left alone, Akhnaton on his throne and Sinuhe on the floor in front of him - small figures.

dialogues.speaker: AKHNATON
dialogues.text: (gently) Come close to me, Sinuhe. Sinuhe looks up in wonder, sess warmth shining in Akhnaton's weary, sick face.

dialogues.speaker: SINUEE
dialogues.text: You are not angry?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is the shepherd angry at the stray lamb which returns to the fold? (anxiously) Have you returned to me, Sinuhe? Looking at him in wonder, Sinuhe gets to his feet. On the way to the throne he plucks the Hittite spearhead out of the table and takes it with him, and supposing that Akhnaton has caused them to be alone so that he can hear the truth as Sinuhe knows it - (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: SINUHE
dialogues.text: The things that Horemheb said about the Hittites --

dialogues.speaker: AKHNATON
dialogues.text: (interrupting, with unexpected violence) Keep that thing from my face! It is an abomination! Weapons are useless! Sinuhe stops, greatly surprised.

dialogues.speaker: AKHNATON
dialogues.text: (gently again, appeal- ingly) Sit here with me. Counsel me if you have any love for me.

dialogues.speaker: SINUHE
dialogues.text: (with amazement) Is this the tone with which Pharaoh addresses a subject?

dialogues.speaker: AKHNATON
dialogues.text: I speak to you as one man to another. Sinuhe sits down on the base of the throne, keeping the spearhead out of Akhnaton's sight.

dialogues.speaker: AKHNATON
dialogues.text: (continues) You have traveled all over the world and you must have gained great wisdom. I have never been able to leave Egypt -- share your wisdom with me.

dialogues.speaker: SINUHE
dialogues.text: (with a wry smile) The things Ilearned in the world.

dialogues.speaker: AKENATON
dialogues.text: (eagerly) What things?

dialogues.speaker: SINUHE
dialogues.text: I saw the people and the rulers. I learned thet whoever rules, it is always the meek and the poor who suffer, I saw the gods and found them all evil. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: AKEWATON
dialogues.text: God is not evil. Believe me, as I sit here -- he is my father in heaven and he has spoken to me, his son. He is a god of love. He commands all men to live as brothers and to love most of all our enemies. To him all men are precious. There is no difference between rich and poor, noble or slave, colored or white. I have proclaimed God's kingdom on earth but some of my people will not believe me. Some call me evil. Some call me mad, My own mother calls me mad. _Sinuhe has a chilling memory of his interview with the Queen Mother.

dialogues.speaker: AKHNATON
dialogues.text: (suffering) Is a man mad, ts he evil, when his only madness, his only evil, is in loving the world?

dialogues.speaker: SINUHE
dialogues.text: (very disturbed) It would be very wonderful if the world could be as Pharaoh imagines it - but it is not.

dialogues.speaker: AKHNATON
dialogues.text: Tt was meant to be! Will you be my friend and help me, Sinuhe? I am so very weak,

dialogues.speaker: SINUHE
dialogues.text: Pharaoh is weak?

dialogues.speaker: AKENATON
dialogues.text: The weakest of all men -- with the biggest task - the biggest burden -- Will you help me?

dialogues.speaker: SINUHE
dialogues.text: (very troubled) I am a physician. I can heal bodies, I have even cured the blind. But I know nothing of bringing light to men's souls, When Pharaoh speaks something moves me which I do not understand -- but I do not know your god. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: AKHNATON
dialogues.text: He is a greater god than you suppose -~- He may be in you, without your kmowl- edge. Exhausted from the emotion he has expended, Akhnaton lies back in his throne, weak, almost fainting. Sinuhe rises and looks at him with worry.

dialogues.speaker: SINUHE
dialogues.text: You are i113 (calls off with a strong voice) Steward! Attend the King!

dialogues.speaker: THEN KAPTAH
dialogues.text: This is immediately after Sinuhe's scene with Akhnaton. He walks toward the gateway, still troubled. He is carrying the Hittite spearhead, now hides it in his belt beneath his clothing. As he comes out of the gate there is a beggar squatted there, with his hands held up for alms. He does not at once recognize the beggar as Kaptah, nor does Kaptah at once recognize Sinuhe.

dialogues.speaker: KAPTAR
dialogues.text: Alms, alms, for the love of the gods! Sinuhe stops, automatically reaching in belt for purse. At the same instant he recognizes Kaptah, and Kaptah recognizes him. Sinuhe begins to smile, Kaptah jumps to his feet.

dialogues.speaker: KAPTAER
dialogues.text: Master, is it you or your spirit?

dialogues.speaker: SINUHE
dialogues.text: (after all that has happened to him) I almost wonder myself.

dialogues.speaker: KAPTAH
dialogues.text: For three days I have been without food! I was sure they had lopped off your head!

dialogues.speaker: AND KAPTAH
dialogues.text: are approaching the Inn - "The Crocodile's Tail." Having apparently been told Sinuhe's news, Kaptah is very much more cheerful.

dialogues.speaker: KAPTAH
dialogues.text: Since you are in favor with Pharaoh once more, we may make a fortune even in this starving land. I suggest speculation in grain ---} During the very last part of this, Sinuhe, without a word, has gone through the gateway into the Inn. Kaptah, caught unawares, goes past gateway, sees that he has lost his master, runs after him.

dialogues.speaker: ROOM
dialogues.text: By the time we reach this scene, Sinuhe has already asked a question of the SERVING GIRL and is being answered ~

dialogues.speaker: SERVING GIRL
dialogues.text: Merit, she's no longer here. Probably you'll find her at Pharaoh's Temple! (practically spits the name) Kaptah hurries into scene just in time to find Sinuhe leaving.
