dialogues.speaker: DAY
dialogues.text: This temple, unlike the temples of the old gods of Egypt, is not roofed, but open to the clear air and the sun. Ir. general pattern, it is an open courtyard surrounded by a high wall with a pyloned gate. There are no dark and mysterious places in this temple. There are no idols, no representations of the fearful gods. Akhnaton's god is represented by two pure symbols. One of these is a rather large Cross of Life, the other is a column of the type we saw when he worshipped on the plains outside Thebes - the type of shaft we call "Cleopatra's Needle,” On the walls there are pictorial decorations. Some of these show the fuller representations of the symbol of Akhnatonts god. In these, god is represented as the disc of the sun from the lower perimeter of which hands reach down in an attitude of benediction, some of these hands holding the Cross of Life. Sometimes scenes of Pharaoh and his Queen and Pharaoh and his whole family are shown with this symbol. There are altars at the bases of the shaft and of the cross. There, is a religious ceremony in progress, and worship- ers, most of whom are of the middle and lower classes, and all of whom wear the Cross of Life, are bringing offerings to the altars - such offerings being chiefly fruits and flowers. The ceremony is being supervised by priests, who are mostly rather young men and are not the fat and oily fellows of the priesthood of the old gods. The worshipers are singing a hymn - one composed by Akhnaton himself. Although this music continues over several succeeding shots, the complete lyrics are given here for convenience: Thy dawning is beautiful in the horizon of heaven, Oh, living Aton, beginning of life! When Thou risest in the eastern horizon of heaven, Thou fillest every land with Thy beauty The two lands of Egypt are in daily festivity, Awake and standing on their feet, Por Thou hast raised them up] The birds flutter in their marshes, Their wings uplifted in adoration te Thee, All the sheep dance upon their feet, All the winged things fly, They live when Thou hast shone upon them. The fish in the river leap up before Thee, (CONTINUED)

dialogues.text: i102. 294 (Cont. ) ‘ And Thy rays are in the midst of the great seal O Thou sole God, whose powers no other possesseth, How manifold are all Thy works!) Their tongues are different in speech, Their forms likewise and their skins, But Thou bindest them all by Thy lovel

dialogues.speaker: ALTAR AT BASE OF SHAFT
dialogues.text: to show the people bringing their offerings, the people singing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: “AND KAPTAH - DAY At first we see only one of the pictorial decorations. Then into scene, walk Sinuhe and Kaptah, looking about with curiosity.

dialogues.speaker: KAPTAE
dialogues.text: This is a temple? Where are ail the dark and mysterious places?

dialogues.speaker: EXT. SHRINE AT BASE OF CROSS OF LIFE
dialogues.text: to show the people bringing their offerings, singing. Among these we see Merit.

dialogues.speaker: MERIT
dialogues.text: as she lays an offering of flowers at the altar. She seems a subtly different person than we knew years ago ~ but only in that she has acquired maturity which has given her calmmess and more quietness.

dialogues.speaker: SINUHE, KAPTAH
dialogues.text: are walking toward the altars. Sinuhe is looking for Merit. It is clear he has not yet seen her. They come upon a YOUNG PRIEST. As Sinuhe and Kaptah stop and Sinuhe looks around, Kaptah engages the Priest in con- versation.

dialogues.speaker: KAPTAR
dialogues.text: Are you a priest? I thought all e priests were fat and oily. The priest smiles. She  5h2 300 301 302 303 30k 103.

dialogues.speaker: MERIT
dialogues.text: turns quickly, having heard Kaptah's voice. Her face lights up with joy and she moves swiftly out of scene.

dialogues.speaker: KAPTAH
dialogues.text: What sort of offerings are these to bring to a god? No slaughtered rams or oxen dripping with rich blood? During this, Merit has entered scene.

dialogues.speaker: MERIT
dialogues.text: (with wonder and joy) Sinuhe, is it you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At the sound of her voice he turns. When he looks at her there is that slight hesitation which reveals that he has not instantly recognized her.

dialogues.speaker: SINUHE
dialogues.text: Merit... ? ANGLE OF THE Two - DAY The smile is wiped off her face. At first she 1s more chagrined than angry.

dialogues.speaker: MERIT
dialogues.text: (with no more than formality) Happy is the day that sees my lord safely returned. She turns away, walking toward the temple gate. Sinuhe reacts, goes after her,

dialogues.speaker: KAPTAH, WORSHIPERS
dialogues.text: Sinuhe quickly catches Merit. Sinuhe is rather pleased that she is piqued at him ~~ it shows that she has missed him, His pleasure shows in kind of a secret smile he has behind everything he says.

dialogues.speaker: SINUHE
dialogues.text: I looked for you at the Inn. I didn't guess I'd find you here. (touches cross on her clothing) Have you taken to religion? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 52 104. 304 (Cont. ) 305 Merit stops and looks at him levelly.

dialogues.speaker: MERIT
dialogues.text: (now a bit angry - with a bite) If you imagine Itve done so to cure & wounded heart, you're mistaken! She pulls free and walks away. Camera moving with them, Sinuhe chases cheerfully after her.

dialogues.speaker: SINUHE
dialogues.text: Where are you going?

dialogues.speaker: MERIT
dialogues.text: To my home.

dialogues.speaker: SINUHE
dialogues.text: May I walk with you?

dialogues.speaker: MERIT
dialogues.text: (ironically - with a bite) My lord's will is mine, as he well imows.

dialogues.speaker: SINUHE
dialogues.text: (conciliatory) Don't be angry with me.

dialogues.speaker: MERIT
dialogues.text: Should I be sweet as honey to someone who left me without a word? She disappears ‘out of sight through the gateway.

dialogues.speaker: SINUHE
dialogues.text: (now slightly alarmed, though serious) There is an explanation -- } He disappears through gates. For a moment we hold on the people entering through and leaving through the gate, the we see Kaptah, who hurries through the gate after Sinuhe and Merit, bent on hearing every word they say, already enjoying himself.

dialogues.speaker: KAPTAH
dialogues.text: Camera is going ahead of Sinuhe and Merit as they walk in the direction which will take them to "The Street to the Docks." Kaptah walks a couple of paces behind them, takin (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 542 105. 305 (Cont.) it all in. Apparently Sinuhe has just concluded a descrip tion of his travels, and apparently the two have not yet become reconciled for -

dialogues.speaker: MERIT
dialogues.text: (still with a sting) The world as you describe it is very large -- and without doubt filled with many fair women. As a physician did you use your talents conscientiously on their behalf? Sinuhe looks at her wondering how to get around her. He laughs and - .

dialogues.speaker: SINUHE
dialogues.text: (with exaggeration which amounts to comedy) Will it please you if I say that not one day has passed but what I have whispered your name to the winds? I sent my greetings to you with the swallows which flew up the Nile.

dialogues.speaker: MERIT
dialogues.text: (suspiciously) I see you have become a man of the world and learned that a pretty lie can be sweeter to a woman than a plain truth. (bantering, seeming to answer him in kind but actually hiding a truth) Then why shouldn't I confess that I have yearned for you when I have laid alone on my mat? When any man has of- fered friendship I have remembered only you. He looks at her, laughing. She laughs in return. Then suddenly he grows more serious, reaches for her hand. Seeing this, she reaches for his. Behind them Kaptah smiles beatifically like a fat duenna.

dialogues.speaker: MERIT
dialogues.text: (simply) I am happy you are here, Sinuhe.

dialogues.speaker: SINUHE
dialogues.text: So am I ~- even if it is a mad world where the only thing that hasn't changed is a woman with a sharp tongue. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MERIT
dialogues.text: (stoutly) Akhnaton is not madJ He looks at her seriously - looks at the Cross of Life sewn on her clothing - perhaps touches it,

dialogues.speaker: SINUHE
dialogues.text: Do you really believe so much?

dialogues.speaker: MERIT
dialogues.text: With all my heart. In this world of a thousand gods, only he has divined the truth -- he is the first in all times to know it -- that there is but one God, who loves us all. For a moment Sinuhe is impressed by the depth of her con- viction.

dialogues.speaker: MERIT
dialogues.text: One day you, too, will believe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.text: (with a wise smile) Or can it be, as people say, that you are made of frozen blocks of Nile water? She locks at him quite differently than ever before, and then, for answer takes his head in her hands and kisses him with fire and passion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Baketamon releases him and whirls away out of scene. Sinuhe stares after her with bewilderment.  126.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She has returned instantly to her passionate anger, is walking about.

dialogues.speaker: BAKETAMON
dialogues.text: Eie caused my mother to be murdered because she opposed Horemheb, but myself he has preserved for their plans! Did they tell you how they hope to dirty the throne?

dialogues.speaker: SINUHE
dialogues.text: (trying to regain his conposurey They did not ...

dialogues.speaker: BAKETAMON
dialogues.text: (raging) Tonight the old priests are to take me to the temple dressed as Sekhmet, the Goddess of War. It will be a sign that the old gods are back in power - and a sign to begin Horemheb's Holy War.

dialogues.speaker: SINUHE
dialogues.text: You have agreed?

dialogues.speaker: BAKETAMON
dialogues.text: In the dead of night Horemheb will come, and the temple gates will be shut behind him! Alone with me, he thinks to have his way with me by force, and by this become a god, fit to rule by my side!

dialogues.speaker: SINUHE
dialogues.text: (impressed with neat- ness of the plan) Horemheb is to be envied,

dialogues.speaker: BAKETAMON
dialogues.text: Not by Sinuhe. As he looks at her with intense surprise she grasps hold of his hands and, sitting on her couch, looks up at him with blazing eyes.

dialogues.speaker: BAKETAMON
dialogues.text: (intensely) If it is Sinuhe who comes to the temple, I will gladly swing the doors shut with my own hands - submit willingly - happily climb the throne to rule with youl (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: SINUHE
dialogues.text: (staring down at her, overwhelmed with the enormity of the idea, bewildered) How is this possible?

dialogues.speaker: BAKETAMON
dialogues.text: The hand which slays Pharaoh can slay the cheesemaker as well, It is only a question of numbers -~ one, or two. --- Is £t possible that you did not understand my mother?

dialogues.speaker: SINUE
dialogues.text: (bewildered by con- flicting thoughts and feelings) The Queen Mother spoke through her ale. Holding his hands she pulls him down on the couch to sit beside her. She continues to hold his hands, and with an air of soft intimacy which is surprising in her -

dialogues.speaker: BAKETAMON
dialogues.text: You are my half-brother - and the rightful heir to the throne. A conviction that she is speaking the truth begins to gro in Sinuhe. It is by no means an altogether welcome though ~ it is a frightening thought - but one which fascinates hin.

dialogues.speaker: BAKETAMON
dialogues.text: While my mother awaited the birth of Akhnaton there was another child born in the palace. For once the black arts of my mother's Nubians had failed. When the mother cried out to see her son, that she might present him to Pharaoh, they showed her a dead girl baby. With her own hands my mother wove the basket in which you were cast adrift on the River. If you doubt me, go to the ruined temple which is near Akhneton's temple. There you will find a statue of the little Queen whose face is the image of your own.

dialogues.speaker: SINUHE
dialogues.text: In the bright moonlight breaking through storm clouds Sinuhe is examining the features of the statue of a delicate, small, young woman. He searches the cold stone, deeply moved with emotion as he tries to find in it the personality of the child Queen whom he is convinced may have,been his mother, After a time -

dialogues.speaker: AT BREAK IN WALL OF TEMPLE
dialogues.text: appears. She enters the temple grounds, stops when she sees -

dialogues.speaker: FROM MERIT'S PERSPECTIVE
dialogues.text: at the statue,

dialogues.speaker: TWO
dialogues.text: brings Merit to Sinuhe. When she is quite near her foot happens to disturb a stone, the sound causing him to turn his head and see her.

dialogues.speaker: MERIT
dialogues.text: (worried) Sinuhe ... ?

dialogues.speaker: SINUHE
dialogues.text: (intensely) How many times I've played here as a child - at war games with Horemheb! How many times I've climbed up this stone - gripped this face with my small boy's grimy hands}

dialogues.speaker: MERIT
dialogues.text: (staring) There are wounded waiting in the temple. He comes to her and for a moment grips her shoulders roughly.

dialogues.speaker: SINUHE
dialogues.text: I have a terrible secret. He goes instantly back to the statue.

dialogues.speaker: MERIT
dialogues.text: I have a secret also, Sinuhe, which it is time I told you. Concerning the boy -- (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 355 (Cont.)

dialogues.speaker: SINUEHE
dialogues.text: (before this registers) This is my mother.

dialogues.speaker: MERIT
dialogues.text: Mother --- ?

dialogues.speaker: SINUHE
dialogues.text: So I have been led to believe. And if this is true then I, Sinuhe, have the blood of the Pharaohs and I, not Akhnaton, might have sat on the throne. This much I know for sure -- tomorrow I can take the throne. (shows her his palm) As easily - (closes his palm) Can you believe this?

dialogues.speaker: MERIT
dialogues.text: (shaken) All things are possible ...

dialogues.speaker: TWO
dialogues.text: as he takes her by the shoulders again, very moved and very much at a loss,

dialogues.speaker: SINUHE
dialogues.text: What shall I do, Merit? The palace reeks with crime - it rots with intrigue -- but what is a man's birth- right -- } (suddenly, rapidly) We will go away! You and I. Come with me. You and I and the boy -- you started to say something about him? ~- There must be some place beyond the reach of all this evil! She feels the force of his appeal as he waits for her answer. After a struggle with herseif -

dialogues.speaker: MERIT
dialogues.text: (in a quiet, rather strange, calm decided way You must take Thoth with you when you take your place at the palace. (as he starts to pro- test) You believed yourself to be an orphan child -- kind people took you in <= do this for him, (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: SINUHE
dialogues.text: But you? I cannot live without youl

dialogues.speaker: MERIT
dialogues.text: (more firmly) It is not fitting for a man to run away, nor can he escape his destiny. Sinuhe -- you will always have the love of your serving girl -- her mat will always be waiting -- forget all else as if it were a dream, and I also will forget.

dialogues.speaker: THOTE'S VOICE
dialogues.text: Moth, , (approaching, yelling) other! - As they turn -

dialogues.speaker: THOTH
dialogues.text: He comes running toward them, wildly excited, gesticu- lating toward Akhnaton's temple. In his hand, like a dagger, he carries the Hittite spearhead.

dialogues.speaker: THOTH
dialogues.text: They are attacking the templel

dialogues.speaker: AT SINUHE AND MERIT
dialogues.text: Sinuhe is climbing onto a heap of ruined wall as Thoth runs in.

dialogues.speaker: AKHNATON'S TEMPLE OF ATON
dialogues.text: This is a comprehensive view which will set up the whole pattern of the attack on Akhnaton's temple. Along the broad ways before the temple, several columns of foot- soldiers are converging for the attack, They carry torches, by which this movement can be discerned - there is a horde. At the head of each colum is being dragged along a great battering ram. The ram of the central column of troops is being taken toward the main gates of the temple; those of the other columms toward positions along the temple walls.

dialogues.speaker: EXT, RUINED TEMPLE
dialogues.text: as Sinuhe scrambles down from the heap of ruined wall,

dialogues.speaker: SINUHE
dialogues.text: We can get in through the side gate. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MERIT
dialogues.text: Thoth! Go home}

dialogues.speaker: THOTH
dialogues.text: No}

dialogues.speaker: AND SOLDIERS OF THE OLD GODS
dialogues.text: The angle is from almost directly behind the battering ra It is being pulled along, on sledges by SLAVES harnessed to it, and by SOLDIERS. PRIESTS OF THE OLD GODS, most of whom are old and fat, shaven, glistening with oil, and wh carry torches, urge on those who pull the ram, We may have an indication of the SOLDIERS who follow after the ram, They are armed with spears of copper and bronze, bows and arrows, stone-tipped war clubs. In b.g. is the wide, wood-and-copper principal gates of the temple - the objective of this ram. On either side of the gates can be seen the tops of some ladders which have been raised from the temple grounds inside. Some DEFENDERS have climbed up onto the walis, are waving such weapons as they have, including staves and farm tools, are shouting their defiance,

dialogues.speaker: EXT, TEMPLE GROUNDS
dialogues.text: The general scene is one of greatest confusion. Some ladders are being thrown up against the walls; some are climbing the ladders; but chiefly it is a scene of dis- order, of wild running to and fro, of fright. There are many women and children in here ~- even more of them than there are men,

dialogues.speaker: MERIT AND THOTH
dialogues.text: are being let in. Bars are thrown across the gate again. Sinuhe goes off in one direction, a definite destination in mind. Thoth runs off in another as Merit tries to stop him. Knocked off balance by someone who is running through -

dialogues.speaker: MERIT
dialogues.text: (calls) Thothl Runs out after him.

dialogues.speaker: AT SECTION OF TEMPLE GROUNDS
dialogues.text: makes his way to the place where previously he has been seen treating the sick and injured. Already there are many who need his services, and a badly injured man who is lying on the ground clutches at his legs. ( CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: WOUNDED MAN
dialogues.text: Help, in God's name}

dialogues.speaker: SINUHE
dialogues.text: In your turn. Make a line, here} Getting to his instruments, he stops as he sees Kaptah.

dialogues.speaker: SINUHE AND KAPTAH
dialogues.text: Sinuhe reacts, especially when he sees that Kaptah is bruised and his fine clothing is torn - signs that he has been fighting.

dialogues.speaker: SINUHE
dialogues.text: Aren't you on the wrong side of the wall?

dialogues.speaker: KAPTAH
dialogues.text: (sheepishly) I followed my master all over the earth ~- now I follow him to destruction,

dialogues.speaker: SINUHE
dialogues.text: Help me make order. (to all) Each in your turn!

dialogues.speaker: RAM
dialogues.text: The ram has been moved to the main gate. Its great arms swing back and then forward with a first shattering impac against the gates, which makes the gates quiver. From the walls up above, a shower of sticks, stones, etc., shower down - a pitiful attempt at answer, Along f.g. a line of soldiers, BOWMEN, can be seen, kneeling, their weapons poised. They let fly a swarm of arrows up toward the top of the wall, The ram arm swings back, forward again with another booming blow.

dialogues.speaker: EXT, TEMPLE GROUNDS
dialogues.text: is helping other women carry wine to the ladders of the fighters - and looking worriedly for Thoth.

dialogues.speaker: MERIT
dialogues.text: Have you seen Thoth?  368 369 370 371 372 373 133.

dialogues.speaker: NIGHT
dialogues.text: In its generalities this scene is a duplicate of that at the main gates. The battering ram is smacking into the wall, which already is showing the signs of previous blows. We see a line of SOLDIERS who, commanded by a PRIEST, kneel to aim their bows and arrows.

dialogues.speaker: DEFENDERS
dialogues.text: The defenders - pitiful in their defense - hurl down a few stones - some roll off large stones. Thoth, his eyes alight, waits, holding in his hands the Hittite spearhead A swarm of arrows flies up into scene. One of them pierce Thoth. He topples backward.

dialogues.speaker: GROUP OF WOMEN
dialogues.text: Thoth falls off the wall to temple grounds, arrow break- ing, leaving stub in his chest. He falls into the midst of a group of women.

dialogues.speaker: NEARBY
dialogues.text: turns at what she sees; a silent scream freszes in her throat.

dialogues.speaker: SINUHE, KAPTAH, WOUNDED
dialogues.text: Sinuhe is working as quickly as he can; there are many wounded. Kaptah is the first to see Merit coming, turns to watch her as she carries Thoth through f.2.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: bring Merit, with Thoth, to Sinuhe and Kaptah. The butt of the arrow projectiong through the boy's chest tells part of the story; Merit's agony tells the rest. Kaptah plucks at Sinuhe's sleeve. Annoyed to be interrupted, Sinuhe turns, sees Merit with Thoth.

dialogues.speaker: MERTT
dialogues.text: Save him!

dialogues.speaker: SINUHE
dialogues.text: (after a struggle) Wait your turn! He turns and works feverishly on the wounded man who has been receiving his attention. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MERIT
dialogues.text: He is your soni Sinuhe whirls and looks at her and the boy again.

dialogues.speaker: SINUHE
dialogues.text: (after a terrible struggle, manages to say - ) In line. He turns back and works furiously. Kaptah comes to Merit. He gently forces her back, camera panning with them away from Sinuhe. He helps her lay the boy on the ground. Her frantic eyes plead with him. But Kaptah can do nothing. 37h EXT. TEMPLE - CLOSE SHOT AT MAIN GATES - BATTERING RA

dialogues.speaker: NIGHT
dialogues.text: In its might is symbolized all the inequality of the struggle. Its great arm swings back, forward with a erash which begins to shatter the gates. There is a roar from the soldiers. The great arm swings back again.

dialogues.speaker: NIGHT
dialogues.text: Defenders, many of them women, press with their hands and their bodies against the gates, trying with their main strength to reinforce the timbers and copper. Ram is heard to crash against the gates - knocks many of the defenders backward off their feet. A crack is opened in the gates. A roar is heard from the soldiers outside.

dialogues.speaker: THOTH AND KAPTAH
dialogues.text: Pinished with the wounded man, Sinuhe hurries to Thoth. Merit watches him with dull eyes as he stoops down to the boy - for she already knows what Sinuhe with a short examination discovers - that the boy has bled to death, He looks up at her with pleading eyes. She turns her back and walks away.

dialogues.speaker: ATTACKING SOLDIERS AND PRIESTS
dialogues.text: With a great blow of the ram the gates are knocked in. Defenders are swept aside and fall beneath the weight of the timbers. The army sweeps in, yelling, weapons waving - a flood of destruction.  378 379 380 361 135.

dialogues.speaker: DEFENDERS
dialogues.text: The wall crumbles as a great hole is knocked in i¢ by a biow of this ram. Those who are on top of the wall come down with the stones, A horde of destruction sweeps through like that at the main gates.

dialogues.speaker: EXT, TEMPLE GROUNDS
dialogues.text: Tt is an hour later. The battle is over, Silence. Fow only the dead.

dialogues.speaker: SINUHE
dialogues.text: Sinuhe is moving among the dead. Presently he comes upon that for which he searches - finds the body of Merit among a pile of dead. He picks her up, carries her to the altar at the foot of the Cross of Life, lays her down next to the body of Thoth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With a torn fragment of altar cloth he covers them. He is bitter, broken. Hatred begins to set the lines of his face. He rises and, camera retreating ahead of him, begins to walk away. The’ arms of a faintly alive woman reach up into scene, trying to clutch at him,

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN
dialogues.text: Help mel

dialogues.speaker: SINUHE
dialogues.text: Help yourselfi As he walks past her his face seta with bitter anger and determination. DISSOLVE TO;  Ske 382 383 136.

dialogues.speaker: TWO SOLDIERS
dialogues.text: A pair of Horemheb's soldiers guard the entrance to Phareach's bedroom. Horemheb and Eie are walking silently together, their backs to camera, They turn as they hear the sound of approaching footsteps. :

dialogues.speaker: SINUHE
dialogues.text: bringing him to them. On his face is seen the bitterness which was there when he walked out of the temple. They hurry into scene to him. Sinuhe stops and looks at them.

dialogues.speaker: EIE
dialogues.text: Does this mean you consent?

dialogues.speaker: SINUHE
dialogues.text: It does. I've had my fill of Akhnaton's kingdom on earth. He unfolds his right hand, shows that he carries a small stone vial.

dialogues.speaker: HOREMHEB
dialogues.text: (excited) Akhnaton is alone in his chamber. My own soldiers are on guard. How will it be given?

dialogues.speaker: SINUHE
dialogues.text: In a cup of wine - (wry smiles) - when you and I drink with him.

dialogues.speaker: HOREMHEB
dialogues.text: (startled)

dialogues.speaker: SINUHE
dialogues.text: We are bound together - as you said. (then getting to business) Spare me one of your guards -- I want a pantry cleared so I can work privately. (going away) Don't fret, Horemheb -- what is needed will be in Pharaoh's cup. He walks out through a door into a corridor. Horemheb, worried, has nothing to do but -

dialogues.speaker: INT, PALACE CORRIDOR
dialogues.text: Sinuhe walks up corridor toward camera. The soldier fol- lows well behind. Sinuhe comes to an opening which leads to a private room and, happening to glance inside, stops.

dialogues.speaker: BAKETAMON, PRIESTS, HANDMAIDENS
dialogues.text: Supervised by Priests of the old gods, Baketamon is being arrayed by HANDMAIDENS in the red robe and jeweled accou~ terments and helmet of the goddess Sekhmet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: sees Sinuhe, Unable to speak because of those present she throws him a look which is at once both an entreaty and a question,

dialogues.speaker: FROM BAKETAMON'S PERSPECTIVE
dialogues.text: bows, goes along.

dialogues.speaker: BAKETAMON
dialogues.text: Smiles with anticipated triumph. Sinuhe's footsteps are heard going down the corridor,

dialogues.speaker: SINUHE
dialogues.text: enters, closing door so guard will remain outside. He selects a bottle of wine, three goblets; opens wine. Into the first of the goblets he pours a small quantity of liq from the stone vial - hesitates a moment = into second go let pours a like quantity. Then into the third goblet he pours a like amount. This latter action is completely inexplicable until we see his next: He picks up a big jar of olive oil, pours a large quantity of oil into a larger drinking vessel, begins to drink it.

dialogues.speaker: PRIESTS
dialogues.text: The procession to the temple of Sekhmet is passing throug to leave the palace - Baketamon, accompanied by Priests, in glory.

dialogues.speaker: HOREMHEB
dialogues.text: looks hungrily at her,

dialogues.speaker: FROM HOREMHEB'S PERSPECTIVE
dialogues.text: looks neither to right nor left. There is a smile on her face,  138.

dialogues.speaker: HOREMHEB AND EIE
dialogues.text: For the first time Baketamon's ignoring of him does not pother Horemheb ~ sure as he is of what will follow this night. He throws a look of amusement at Eie, then both go to meet Sinuhe as the latter comes in, carrying a tray on which are three drinking cups of wine. Sinuhe hands the tray to Horemheb with a rather strange smile.

dialogues.speaker: SINUHE
dialogues.text: So let it be.

dialogues.speaker: HOREMHEB
dialogues.text: Which is his?

dialogues.speaker: SINUHE
dialogues.text: The one he will take. He goes to Akhnaton's doorway, where he waits. Horemheb summons his nerve, goes through into the room, Sinuhe follows.

dialogues.speaker: AKHNATON
dialogues.text: Only dim lights - semidarkness, This room is rather simpl It's principal decoration is painted on the wail behind t head of Akhnaton's sleeping couch -- the full symbol of h god ~~ the sun's-disc with hands in benediction holding the Cross of Life. On a table by the sleeping couch rests the crown, the crook and other symbols of kingship. Akhna lies very still on the couch, his head on the headrest. Sinuhe and Horemheb approach him quietly.

dialogues.speaker: NIGHT
dialogues.text: For a moment they look down at him, thinking that Akhnato is asleep, but then he opens his eyes,

dialogues.speaker: AKHNATON
dialogues.text: (as if he has expected them) Ah,

dialogues.speaker: HOREMHEB
dialogues.text: (with friendly cordiality) We beg leave to drink wine with you, Akhnaton, in token of friendship. I regret my words on the roof top and believe that tomorrow the prospects for Egypt will be brighter. Akhnaton gives him an odd, twisted smile, his eyes shift Sinuhe.

dialogues.speaker: AKENATON
dialogues.text: De you bring me peace, Sinuhe? she (CONTINUED)  139. 395 (Cont.) 396 He reaches out and takes one of the goblets. Horemheb, nervous, makes sure that Akhnaton is looking at the goble shifts his eyes quickly to Sinuhe in question, Sinuhe nod Satisfied, Horemheb sets the tray with the other two gob- lets on a small table by the couch, Akhnaton looks at the and with a gesture invites them to be seated.

dialogues.speaker: HOREMHEB
dialogues.text: (cheerfully) Like old times. Do you remember when we three met on the dessert - young men «=~ ?

dialogues.speaker: AKHNATON
dialogues.text: (disregarding him, to Sinuhe) If you bring me peace, it will be sweeter than the scent of myrrh. With a sudden, surprisingly swift motion, he drains the goblet. A half-gesture from Sinuhe is too late. As Horemheb watches with great suspense, Akhnaton sighs, let the goblet roll from his hand and lays his head back onto the headrest.

dialogues.speaker: HOREMHEB
dialogues.text: (with satisfaction) Much brighter, tomorrow,

dialogues.speaker: AKHNATON
dialogues.text: (fervently) Sinuhe! Harken to me! God has not for- saken me, When you left me on the roof top - as darkness descended ~ I saw the true light. All things I have spoken I had from God! I die, not because I tried to deceive the world, but because I tried to make it noble. -= With what difficulty does God try to reveal Himself - for we, His children, are blind and stupid. For ages, through the great circle of time, He has tried -- He tried with me -- I was frail and weak but He has shown me His love, permitting me to die in His cause. I tell you - I was the shadow of One Who will come -- the Mighty One -- a King of Kings! (weakening) I was a shadow to walk before Him ... He stops talking, and Horemheb and Sinuhe, looking at him Yaderstand that he is dead. For a long moment they are silent, then - (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 396 (Cont.)

dialogues.speaker: SINUHE
dialogues.text: (more to himself than 6 Horemheb) Why have I done this? Was it for the good of Egypt? Was it because he asked me, and I loved him -- did I hate hin, because of Merit and Thoth? Or is it written that a man must live his life until his cup be full to overflowing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Horemheb rises and looks down at Akhnaton, He takes off his cloak and, as he did in the desert, spreads it over the still, frail form, He straightens, rises to his full height, seems to expand.

dialogues.speaker: HOREMHEB
dialogues.text: This is the hour I have awaited all my life. (with a kind of awe) I am Egypt now! : He picks up his goblet, raises it.

dialogues.speaker: SINUHE
dialogues.text: (fascinated, quietly) Horemheb ...

dialogues.speaker: HOREMHEB
dialogues.text: And I will do such deeds for her glory -~ !

dialogues.speaker: SINUHE
dialogues.text: Don't drink it, Horemheb looks an astonished question at him.

dialogues.speaker: SINUHE
dialogues.text: Or you will not be Egypt - or any - thing. Slowly comprehension dawns on Horemheb. The hand which holds the goblet begins to tremble; he drops the goblet which rings on the floor, and wine splashes everywhere,

dialogues.speaker: SINUHE
dialogues.text: Go to the temple, Horemheb --

dialogues.speaker: HOREMHEB
dialogues.text: (fright growing into anger) You dared - ?

dialogues.speaker: SINUHE
dialogues.text: Baketamon waits. she (CONTINUED)  She 397 (Cont.) yl. SINUHE (Cont.) (walking away into room) She will be greatly surprised, for it is not you she expects, and no doubt the claws of the lioness goddess will rip into you - but you can prevail. (on the other side of cot, looks at crown, etc. on table) Go to the temple, climb the throne - (throws crown more at him than to him) - receive your crown and bless my name, for I, an insignificant physician, have make you Pharaoh!

dialogues.speaker: HOREMHEB
dialogues.text: You really dared,

dialogues.speaker: SINUHE
dialogues.text: Yes, I dared and dare now, had not Akhnaton's last words saved us both, Wear the dirty crown! --

dialogues.speaker: HOREMHEB
dialogues.text: This was treason! I will --

dialogues.speaker: SINUHE
dialogues.text: (with scorn) You will, will, what you will! You will go to war and win a battle? You will con= quer and not know that it is defeat? You will raise Egypt to glory, and watch her die? Horemheb, the crown is heavy, and you will wear it with sorrow. We live in the twilight of Egypt, and you will be her sunset. Wations rise, only to fall - races die out - kings build mighty monuments, only to have them crumble into dust - glory flees like a shadow -- all these things are earthly, and have the seed of death in them. Only a thought can live = only a great truth can grow and flourish, and a truth cannot be killed. It passes in secret from one man's heart to another - it is given in a mother's milk to her child ~~ How many upheavals must occur, how many people be swept from the face of the earth before the truth shines in glory, but it will, it will ...

dialogues.speaker: HOREMHEB
dialogues.text: Horemheb has recovered his composure, has measured his strength against Sinuhe's with satisfaction, (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 398 (Cont.) 399 4.00 4o1 4o2 She ANGLE To

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: lke.

dialogues.speaker: HOREMHEB
dialogues.text: (with amused scorn) Are you trying to tell me that you will fight against me, Sinuhe?

dialogues.speaker: SINUHE
dialogues.text: Oh, you will win that too - you will silence me, But not for a long time, for we are bound together, you and I -~ the knowledge of a mutual crime forms bonds even stronger than those of friendship - and until you do silence me ---

dialogues.speaker: EHOREMHEB
dialogues.text: (with amused scorn) Yes - and what will you do, physician?

dialogues.speaker: SINUHE
dialogues.text: with camera moving very slowly to him during -

dialogues.speaker: SINUEE
dialogues.text: (simply, but with increasing, calm fervor) I will go amongst the people and speak of the God who loves us all. I will wear the clothes of slaves and kick the sandals off my feet and speak to the wives as they fry their fish before their mud huts by the river - to the porters on the docks = to the smiths at their bellows = to the mer- chants who mix sand with flour - to the mill owners who gag their slaves that they might not eat the corn they grind = to the judges who give wrong judgments for bribes - to the nobles who will set their dogs on me ~= and I will say:

dialogues.speaker: OLD SINUHE
dialogues.text: as he continues directly -

dialogues.speaker: OLD SINUHE
dialogues.text: There is no difference between one man and another, for all are born naked into the (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 402 (Cont.) 403 kok hos 406 407 OLD SINUHE (Cont.) world, A man cannot be measured by the color of his skin, or by his speech, or by his clothes and jewels, but only by his heart.
